note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

div.head: Scena Prima.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: _DIſſwade me not.

sp.speaker: Clere.
sp.l: It will breed a braule.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I care not, I weare a Sword.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: And weare diſcretion with it,
Or caſt it off, let that direct your arme,
'Tis madneſſe els, not valour, and more baſe
Then to receive a wrong.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Why would you have me
Sit downe with a diſgrace, and thanke the doer?
We are not Stoicks, and that paſſive courage
Is onely now, commendable in Lackies,
Peaſants, and Tradeſemen, not in men of ranke,
And qualitie, as I am.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Doe not cheriſh
That daring vice, for which the whole age ſuffers
The blood of our bold youth, that heretofore
Was ſpent in honourable action,
Or to defend, or to enlarge the Kingdome,
For the honour of our Countrey, and our Prince,
Poures it ſelfe out, with prodigall expence
Upon our Mothers lap, the Earth that bred us
For every trifle, and theſe private Duells,
Which had their firſt originall from the French;
(And for which, to this day, we are juſtly cenſured)
And baniſht from all civill Governments
Scarce three in Venice, in as many yeares;
In Florence, they are rarer, and in all
The faire Dominions of the Spaniſh King,
They are never heard of: Nay, thoſe neighbour Countries,,
Which gladly imitate our other follies,
And come at a deare rate to buy them of us,
Begin now to deteſt them.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Will you? and yet—

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: And I have heard, that ſome of our late Kings,
For the lie, wearing of a Miſtris, feathers;
A cheate at Cards or Dice and ſuch like cauſes,
Have loſt as many gallant Gentlemen,
As might have met the great Turke in the field
With confidence of a glorious Victorie,
And ſhall we then—

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: No more, for ſhame no more,
Are you become a Patron to? 'tis a new one,
No more on't, burn't, give it to ſome Orator,
To help him to enlarge his exerciſe,
With ſuch a one, it might doe well, and profit
The Curat of the Pariſh, but for Cleremont
The bold, and under-taking Cleremont,
To talke thus to his friend his friend that knowes him,
Dinant, that knowes his Cleremont, is abſurd,
And meere Apocripha.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Why, what know you of me?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Why if thou haſt forgot thy ſelfe, I'll tell thee,
And not looke backe, to ſpeake of what thou wert
At fifteene, for at thoſe yeares, I have heard
Thou waſt fleſh'd, and enter'd bravely.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Well ſir, well.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: But yeſterday, thou waſt the common ſecond,
Of all that onely knew thee, thou hadſt bills
Set up on every poſt, to give thee notice,
Where any difference was, and who were parties,
And as, to ſave the charges of the Law;
Poore men ſeeke Arbitrators, thou wert choſen
By ſuch as knew thee not, to compound quarrells:
But thou wert ſo delighted with the ſport,
That if there were no juſt cauſe, thou wouldſt make one,
Or be engag'd thy ſelfe: This godly calling
Thou haſt followed five and twenty yeares, and ſtudied
The Criticiſmes of contentions, and art thou
In ſo few houres transform'd? certaine this night
Thou haſt had ſtrange dreames, or rather viſions.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Yes, Sir,
I have ſeene fooles, and fighters, chain'd together,
And the Fighters had the upper hand and whipt firſt,
The poore Sotts laughing at 'em. What I have bin
It skils not, what I will be is reſolv'd on.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Why then you'll fight no more?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Such is my purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: On no occaſion?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: There you ſtagger me,
Some kind of wrongs there are, which fleſh and blood
Cannot endure.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Thou wouldſt not willingly,
Live a proteſted coward, or be call'd one?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Words, are but words.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Nor would'ſt thou take a blow?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Not from my friend, though drunke, and from an enemy,
I thinke much leſſe.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: There's ſome hope of thee left then.
Wouldſt thou heare me, behind my back diſgrac'd?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Do you think I am a rogue? they that ſhould do it
Had better bin borne dumbe.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Or in thy preſence?
See me o're-charg'd with odds?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I'd fall my ſelfe firſt.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Would'ſt thou endure thy Miſtris be taken from thee,
And thou ſit quiet?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: There you touch my honour,
No French man can endure that.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Pl— upon thee,
Why doſt thou talke of Peace then? that dar'ſt ſuffer
Nothing, or in thy ſelfe, or in thy friend
That is unmanly?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: That I grant, I cannot:
But I'll not quarrell with this Gentleman,
For wearing ſtammell Breeches, or this Gameſter,
For playing a thouſand pounds, that owes me nothing;
For this mans taking up a common Wench
In raggs, and lowſie, then maintaining her
Caroached in cloth of Tiſſue, nor five hundred
Of ſuch like toyes, that at no part concerne me;
Marry, where my honour, or my friend is queſtioned,
I have a Sword, and I thinke I may uſe it
To the cutting of a Raſcalls throat, or ſo,
Like a good Chriſtian.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Thou art of a fine Religion,
And rather then we'll make a Schiſme in friendſhip,
I will be of it: But to be ſerious,
Thou art acquainted with my tedious love-ſuit
To faire Lamira.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Too well Sir, and remember
Your preſents, courtſhip, that's too good a name,
Your ſlave-like ſervices, your morning muſique;
Your walking three houres in the raine at midnight,
To ſee her at her window, ſometimes laugh'd at,
Sometimes admitted, and vouchſaf'd to kiſſe
Her glove, her skirt, nay I have heard, her ſlippers,
How then you triumph'd?
Here was love forſooth.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Theſe follies I deny not,
Such a contemptible thing, my dotage made me,
But my reward for this —

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: As you deſerv'd.
For he that makes a goddeſſe of a Puppet,
Merits no other recompence.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: This day friend,
For thou art ſo —

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I am no flatterer.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: This proud, ingratefull ſhe, is married to
Lame Champernell.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I know him, he has bin
As tall a Sea-man, and has thriv'd as well by't,
The loſſe of a legg and an Arme deducted, as any
That ever put from Marſeils: you are tame,
Pl— on't, it mads me; if it were my caſe,
I ſhould kill all the family.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Yet but now
You did preach patience.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I then came from confeſſion,
And 't was enjoyn'd me three houres for a pennance,
To be a peaceable man, and to talke like one,
But now, all elſe being pardon'd, I begin
On a new Tally, Foot doe any thing,
I'll ſecond you.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I would not willingly
Make red, my yet white conſcience, yet I purpoſe
In the open ſtreet, as they come from the Temple,
(For this way they muſt paſſe,) to ſpeake my wrongs,
And doe it boldly. Muſick playes.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Were thy tongue a Cannon,
I would ſtand by thee, boy, they come, upon 'em.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Obſerue a little firſt.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: This is fine fidling.

div.stage: Enter Vertaigne, Champernell Lamira, Nurſe, Beaupre Verdoone.

body.head: An Epithalamin Song at the Wedding.

lg.l: COme away bring on the Bride
And place her by her Lovers ſide:
You faire troope of Maides attend her,
Pure and holy thoughts be friend her.
Bluſh, and wiſh, you Virgins all
Many ſuch faire nights may fall
Hymen, fill the houſe with joy,
Bleſſe the Bed, with holy love,
Now faire or be of Beauty move.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Stand by, for 'twill be heard.

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: This is ſtrange rudeneſſe.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: 'Tis courtſhip, ballanced with injuries,
You all looke pale with guilt, but I will dy
Your cheekes with bluſhes, if in your ſear'd veines,
There yet remaine ſo much of honeſt blood
To make the colour; firſt to ye my Lord,
The Father of this Bride, whom you have ſent
Alive into her grave.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: How? to her grave?

sp.speaker: Dina.
sp.l: Be patient ſir, I'll ſpeake of you anon,
You that allowed me liberall acceſſe,
To make my way with ſervice, and approv'd of
My birth, my perſon, yeares, and no baſe fortune:
You that are rich, and but in this held wiſe too,
That as a Father ſhould have look'd upon
Your Daughter in a Husband, and aim'd more
At what her youth, and heat of blood requir'd
In lawfull pleaſures, then the parting from
Your Crownes to pay her dowre: you that already
Have one foot in the grave, yet ſtudy profit,
As if you were aſſur'd, to live here ever;
What poore end had you, in this choice? in what
Deſerve I your contempt? my houſe, and honours,
At all parts equall yours, my fame as faire,
And not to praiſe my ſelfe, the City rankes me,
In the firſt file, of her moſt hopefull Gentry:
But Champernell is rich, and needs a nurſe,
And not your gold: And add to that, he's old too,
His whole eſtate in likelihood, to deſcend
Upon a Family; Here was providence,
I grant, but in a Nobleman, baſe thrift:
No Merchants, nay, no Pirats, ſell for Bondmen.
Their Countrey-men, but you, a Gentleman,
To ſave a little gold have ſold your Daughter
To worſe then ſlaverie.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: This was ſpoke home indeed.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.l: Sir, I ſhall take ſome other time to tell you,
That this harſh language, was delivered to
An old man, but my Father.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: At your pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Proceed in your deſigne, let me alone,
To anſwer him, or any man.

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: You preſume
Too much upon your name, but may be couſin'd.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: But for you, moſt unmindfull of my ſervice,
For now I may upbraid you, and with honour,
Since all is loſt, and yet I am a gainer,
In being deliver'd from a torment in you,
For ſuch you muſt have bin, you to whom nature
Gave with a liberall hand, moſt excellent forme,
Your education, language, and diſcourſe,
And judgement to diſtinguiſh when you ſhall
With feeling ſorrow, underſtand how wretched
And miſerable, you have made your ſelfe,
And but your ſelfe, have nothing to accuſe,
Can you with hope from any beg compaſſion?
But you will ſay, you ſerv'd your Fathers pleaſure,
Forgetting that unjuſt commands of Parents
Are not to be obey'd, or that you are rich,
And that to wealth, all pleaſure els are ſervants,
Yet but conſider, how this wealth was purchas'd,
'Twill trouble the poſſeſſion.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: You ſir know
I got it, and with honour.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: But from whom?
Remember that, and how: you'll come indeed
To houſes bravely furniſh'd, but demanding
Where it was bought, this ſouldier will not lie,
But anſwer truly, this rich cloth of Arras,
I made my prize in ſuch a Ship, this Plate
Was my ſhare in another; theſe faire Jewells,
Comming a ſhore, I got in ſuch a Village,
The Maid, or Matron kill'd, from whom they were raviſh'd,
The Wines you drinke, are guilty too, for this,
This Candie Wine, three Merchants were undone,
Theſe Suckets breake as many more, in briefe,
All you ſhall weare, or touch, or ſee, is purchas'd
By lawleſſe force, and you but revell in
The teares, and grones, of ſuch as were the owners.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: 'Tis falſe, moſt baſely falſe.

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Let looſers talke.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Laſtly, thoſe joyes, thoſe beſt of joyes, which Hymen
Freely beſtowes on ſuch, that come to tye
The ſacred knot he bleſſes, wonne unto it
By equall love, and mutuall affection,
Not blindly led, with the deſire of riches,
Moſt miſerable you, ſhall never taſte of,
This Marriage night, you'll meet a Widowes bed,
Or failing of thoſe pleaſures, all Brides looke for,
Sinne in your wiſh it were ſo,

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Thou art a Villaine,
A baſe, malitious ſlauderer.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Strike him.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: No, he is not worth a blow.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: O that I had thee
In ſome cloſe vault that onely would yeild roome
To me to uſe my Sword, to thee no hope
To run away, I would make thee on thy knees,
Bite out the tongue that wrong'd me.

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Pray you have patience.

sp.speaker: Lamira.
sp.l: This day I am to be your Soveraigne,
Let me command you.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: I am loſt with rage,
And know not what I am my ſelfe, nor you:
Away, dare ſuch as you, that love the ſmoke
Of peace, more then the fire of glorious Warre,
And like unprofitable drones, feed on
Your grandſires laboures, that, as I am now,
Were gathering Bees, and fil'd their Hive, this Country
With brave triumphant ſpoiles, cenſure our Actions?
You object my prizes to me, had you ſeene
The horrour of a Sea-fight, with what danger
I made them mine; the fire I feareleſſe fought in
And quench'd it in mine enemies blood, which ſtraight
Like Oyle pour'd out on't, made it burne anew;
My Deck blowne up, with noiſe enough to mocke
The lowdeſt thunder, and the deſperate fooles
That Boorded me, ſent to defie the tempeſt
That were againſt me to the angrie Sea,
Frighted with men throwen ore; no victory,
But in deſpight of the foure Elements,
The Fire, the Ayre, the Sea, and ſands hid in it
To be atchiev'd, you would confeſſe poore men,
(Though hopeleſſe, ſuch an honourable way
To get or wealth, or honour) in your ſelves;
He that through all theſe dreadfull paſſages,
Purſued and overtooke them, unafrighted,
Deſerves reward, and not to have it ſtild
By the baſe name of theft.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: This is the Courtſhip,
That you muſt looke for, Madam.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: 'Twill doe well,
When nothing can be done, to ſpend the night with:
Your tongue is ſound, good Lord, I could wiſh
For this young Ladyes ſake this leg, this arme,
And there is ſomething els I will not name,
(Though 'tis the onely thing that muſt content her)
Had the ſame vigour.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: You ſhall buy theſe ſcoffes
With your beſt blood, helpe me once noble anger,
(Nay ſtirre not, I alone muſt right my ſelfe)
And with one leg tranſport me to correct
Theſe ſcandalous praters: ô that noble wounds Falls.
Should hinder juſt revenge? D'ye jeere me too?
I got theſe not as you doe your diſeaſes
In Brothells, or with riotous abuſe
Of wine in Tavernes; I have one leg ſhot,
One arme diſabled, and am honour'd more,
By looſing them as I did in the face
Of a brave enemy then if they were
As when I put to Sea; you are French men onely,
In that you have bin laied, and cur'd, goe to:
You mock my leg but every bone about you,
Makes you good Almanack-makers, to foretell
What wether we ſhall have.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Put up your Sword.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Or turne it to a Crutch, there't may be uſefull,
And live, on the relation to your Wife,
Of what a brave man you were once.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: And tell her
What a fine vertue, 'tis in a young Lady
To give an old man pap.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Or hire a Surgeon
To teach her to roule up your broken limbes.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: To make a Pulteſſe, and endure the ſent
Of oiles and naſty Plaiſters.

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: Fie ſir, fie,
You that have ſtood all dangers of all kinds,
To yeild to a rivalls ſcoffe?

sp.speaker: L●mira.
sp.l: Shed teares upon
Your Wedding day? this is unmanly Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: They are teares of anger o that I ſhould live
To play the woman thus? All powerfull heaven,
Reſtore me, but one houre, that ſtrength agen,
That I had once, to chaſtiſe in theſe men,
Their follies, and ill manners, and that done,
When you pleaſe, I'll yeild up the fort of life,
And doe it gladly

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: We ha' the better of him,
We ha' made him crye.

sp.speaker: Verdo.
sp.l: You ſhall have ſatisfaction,
And I will doe it nobly, or diſclaime me.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: I ſay no more you have a Brother, Siſter,
This is your Wedding day, we are in the ſtreete,
And howſoever, they forget their honour,
'Tis fit I looſe not mine, by their example.

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: If there be Lawes in Paris looke to anſwer
This inſolent affront

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: You that live by them,
Study 'em for heavens ſake; for my part I know not
Nor care not what they are, Is their ought els
That you would ſay?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Nothing, I have my ends,
Lamira weepes, I have ſaid too much I feare;
So dearely once I lov'd her, that I cannot
Endure to ſee her teares. Exiunt. Dionant and Cleremont.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: See you performe it,
And doe it like my Nephew.

sp.speaker: Verdo.
sp.l: If I faile in't
Nere know me more, Couſen Beupro

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Repent not
What thou haſt done, my life, thou ſhalt not find
I am decrepit; in my love, and ſervice,
I will be young, and conſtant, and beleeve me,
For thou ſhall find it true, in ſcorne of all
The ſcandalls theſe rude men have throwne upon me
I'le meete thy pleaſures, with a young mans ardour
And in all circumſtances, of a Husband,
Performe my parts.

sp.speaker: Lamira.
sp.l: Good Sir, I am your ſervant,
And 'tis too late now, if I did repent,
(Which as I am a virgin yet, I doe not)
To undoe the knot, that by the Church is tyed
Onely I would beſeech ye, as you have,
A good opinion of me, and my vertues,
For ſo you have pleas'd to ſtile my innocent weakenes,
That what hath paſs'd beween Dinant and me,
Or what now in your hearing he hath ſpoken,
Beget not doubts, or feares.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: I apprehend you,
You thinke I will be jealous, as I live
Thou art miſtaken ſweet; and to confirme it
Diſcourſe with whom thou wilt, ride where thou wilt,
Feaſt whom thou wilt, as often as thou wilt,
For I will have no other guards upon thee
Then thine owne thoughts,

sp.speaker: Lamira.
sp.l: I'le uſe this liberty
With moderation Sir,

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: I am reſolv'd
Steale off, i'le follow you,

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Come Sir, you droope,
Till you find cauſe, which I ſhall never give
Diſlike not of your ſon in Law,

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Sir, You teach me
The language I ſhould uſe; I am moſt happy
In being ſo neere you. Exeunt Verdone and Beaupre.

sp.speaker: Lamira.
sp.l: O my feares good nurſe
Follow my Brother unobſerv'd and learne,
Which way he takes.

sp.speaker: Nurſ.
sp.l: I will be carefull Madam. Exit Nurſe.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Betweene us complements are ſuperfluous,
One Gentlemen, th' affront we have met here
Wee'l thinke upon hereafter, 'twere unfit
To cheriſh any thought to breed unreſt,
Or to our ſelves, or to our Nuptiall feaſt.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: We ſhall have ſport, ner fear't

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: What ſport I prithee?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Why we muſt fight, I know it, and I long for't
It was apparent in the fiery eye,
Of young Verdoone, Beaupre look'd pale and ſhooke too,
Familiar ſignes of anger. They are both brave fellowes
Tride and approv'd, and I am prou'd to encounter.
With men, from whom no honour can be loſt
They will play up to a man, and ſet him off,
When ere I goe to the field, heaven keepe me from
The meeting of an unfleſh'd youth or Coward,
The firſt to get a name, comes on too hot,
The Coward is ſo ſwift in giving ground,
There is no overtaking him, without
A hunting Nag, well breath'd too.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: All this while,
You ne'r thinke on the danger,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Why 'tis no more,
Then meeting of a douſen Friends at Supper,
And drinking hard; miſcheif comes there unlook'd for,
I am ſure as ſuddaine, and ſtrikes home as often,
For this we are prepar'd

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Lamira Loves
Her Brother Beaupre dearely.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: What of that?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: And ſhould he call me to account for what
But now I ſpeake, nor can I with mine honour
Recant my words, that little hope is left me,
'Ere to enjoye what (next to heaven I long for,)
Is taken from me,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Why what can you hope for,
She being now married?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: On my Cleremont,
To you all ſecrets of my heart lye open,
And I reſt moſt ſecure that whatſoer'e
I looke up there, is as a private thought,
And will no farther wrong me, I am a Frenchman,
And for the greater part, we are borne Courtiers,
She is a woman, and how ever yet,
No heat of ſervice, had the power to melt
Her frozen Chaſtity, time and opportunitie
May worke her to my ends, I confeſſe ill ones,
And yet I muſt purſue 'em: now her marriage,
In probabilitie, will no way hurt,
But rather help me,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Sits the wind there? pray you tell me
How farr off, dwells your love from luſt?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Too neere,
But prithee chide me not,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Not I, goe on boye,
I have faults my ſelf, and will not reprehend
A crime I am not free from: for her Marriage,
I doe eſteeme it (and moſt batchellors are
Of my opinion) as a faire protection,
To play the wanton, without loſſe of honour.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Would ſhe make riſe of't ſo, I were moſt happy.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: No more of this, Judge now,
Whither I have the guift of prophecie.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: Monſieur Dinant.
I am glad to find you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I am at your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: Good Monſieur Cleremont, I have long wiſh'd
To be knowne better to you,

sp.speaker: Cl●r.
sp.l: My deſires
Embrace your wiſhes Sir,

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: Sir, I have ever
Eſteem'd you truly noble, and profeſſe.
I ſhould have bin moſt proud, to have had the honour,
To call you Brother, but my Fathers pleaſure
Denied that happineſſe, I know no man lives,
That can command his paſſions, and therefore
Dare not condemne, the late intemperate language
You were pleas'd to uſe, to my Father and my Siſter
Hee's old and ſhe a woman, I moſt ſortie,
My honour does compell me to entreat you,
To doe me the favour, with your ſword to meete me
A mile without the Citie.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: You much honour me.
In the demand, I'l gladly waite upon you,

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: O Sir you teach me what to ſay: the time?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: With the next Sun, if you thinke fit.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: The place.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Nere to the vineyard eaſtward from the Citie,

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: I like it well, this gentleman if you pleaſe
Will keepe me company,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: That is agreed on;
And in my friends behalf I will attend him

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: You ſhall not miſſe my ſervice.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: Good day Gentlemen. Ex. Beaup. and Virdoone.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: At your Commandement.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Prou'd to be your ſervants,
I thinke there is no Nation under heaven
That cut their enemies throates with complement,
And ſuch fine trickes as we doe: If you have
Any few Prayers to ſay, this night you may
Ca l'em to mind and uſe 'em, for my ſelf,
As I have little to looſe, my care is leſſe,
So till to morrow morning, I bequeath you,
To your devotions; and thoſe payed, but uſe
That noble courage I have ſeene, and we
Shall fight, as in a Caſtle,

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Thou art all honour,
Thy reſoultion, would ſteele a Coward,
And I moſt fortunate, in ſuch a Friend,
All tenderneſſe, and nice reſpect of woman,
Be now far from me, reputation take
A full poſſeſſion of my heart, and prove
Honour the firſt place holds, the ſecond love. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lamir.
sp.l: Sleepes my Lord ſtill Carlote.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Not to be wak'd
By your Ladiſhips cheerefull lookes, I well perceive
That this night, the good Lord hath bin
At an unuſuall ſervice, and no wonder
If he reſt after it

sp.speaker: Lamir.
sp.l: You are very bold

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Your Creature Madam and when you are pleas'd
Sadneſſe to me's a ſtranger, your good pardon
If I ſpeake like a foole, I could have wiſht,
To have taine your place to night, had bold Dinant
Your firſt and moſt obſequious ſervant taſted
Thoſe delicates, which by his lethargie
As it appeares, have cloyed my Lord,

sp.speaker: Lamira.
sp.l: No more.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: I am ſilenc'd Madam

sp.speaker: Lamira.
sp.l: Saw you my nurſe this morning?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: No Madam.

sp.speaker: Lamira.
sp.l: I am full of feares. Knock within.
Who's that?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: She you enquir'd for

sp.speaker: Lamira.
sp.l: Bring her in, and leave me. Ex. Charlote. Enter Nurſe.
Now nurſe what newes.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: O Ladie dreadfull ones,
They are to fight this morning, ther's no remedie
I ſaw my Lord your Brother, and Verdoone.
Take horſe as I came by,

sp.speaker: Lamir.
sp.l: Wher's Cleremont?

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: I met him too, and mounted.

sp.speaker: Lamir.
sp.l: Wher's Dinant?

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: There's all the hope, I have ſtaied him with a tricke,
If I have done well ſo,

sp.speaker: Lamir.
sp.l: What tricke?

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: I 'tould him,
Your Ladiſhip layed your command upon him,
To attend you preſently, and to confirme it,
Gave him the ring' he oft hath ſeene you weare,
That you beſtowed on me; he waites without
Diſguis'd, and if you have that power in him,
As I preſume you have, it is in you
To ſtay or alter him.

sp.speaker: Lamir.
sp.l: Have you learnt the place,
Where they are to encounter?

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: Yes 'tis where
The Duke of Burgundie, met Lewis th' eleventh

sp.speaker: Lamir.
sp.l: Enough I will reward thee liberally, Ex. Nurſe.
Goe bring him in, full deare I lov'd Dinant,
While it was lawfull, but thoſe fires are quenched,
I being now anothers, truth forgive me
And let diſſimulation, be no crime,
Though moſt unwillingly, I put it on
To guard a Brothers ſafetie.

sp.speaker: Dina.
sp.l: Now your pleaſure,
Though ill you have deſerv'd it, you perſev'd
I am ſtill your foole, and cannot but obey
What ever you command

sp.speaker: Lamir.
sp.l: You ſpeake as if
You did repent it and 'tis not worth my thankes then,
But there has bin a time, in which you would
Receive this as a favour

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Hope was left then
Of recompence.

sp.speaker: Lamir.
sp.l: Why I am ſtill Lamira.
And you Dinant and 'tis yet in my power
I dare not ſay, i'll put it into act,
To reward your love and ſervice,

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Ther's ſome comfort,

sp.speaker: Lamir.
sp.l: But thinke not that ſo low I przie my fame,
To give it up to any man that refuſes
To buy it, or with danger or performance
Of what I ſhall enjoine him,

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Name that danger
Be it of what horrid ſhape ſoever Ladie
Which I will ſhrinke at; only at this inſtant
Be ſpeedie in't

sp.speaker: Lamir.
sp.l: I'll put you to the triall:
You ſhall not fight to day, doe you ſtart at that?
Not with my Brother, I have heard ●our difference,
Mine is no Helens beauty, to be purchas'd
With blood, and ſo defended if you looke for
Favours from me, deſerve them with obedience,
Ther's no way els to gain 'em

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: You command
What with mine honour I cannot obey
Which lies at pawne againſt it and a friend
Equally deare as that, or life engag'd,
Not for himſelf, but me.

sp.speaker: Lamir.
sp.l: Why, fooliſh man,
Dare you ſollicite me, to ſerve your luſt,
In which not onely, I abuſe my Lord,
My father, and my family, but write whore,
Though not upon my forhead, in my conſcience,
To be read howerly, and yet name your honours?
Yours ſuffer but in circumſtance; mine in ſubſtance,
If you obey me, you part with ſome credit,
From whom? the giddy multitude; but mankind
Will cenſure me, and juſtly

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I will looſe,
What moſt I doe deſire, rather then hazard
So deare a friend, or write my ſelfe a coward,
'Tis better be no man

sp.speaker: Lamir.
sp.l: This will not doe;
Why I deſire not, you ſhould be a coward,
Nor doe I weigh my Brothers life with yours,
Meete him, fight with him, doe, and kill him fairely,
Let me not ſuffer f r you, I am careleſſe.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Suffer for me?

sp.speaker: Lamir.
sp.l: For you, my kindneſſe to you,
Already brands me, with a ſtrumpets name,

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: O that I knew the wretch!

sp.speaker: Lamir.
sp.l: I will not name him,
Nor give you any Character to know him;
But if you dare, and inſtantly ride foorth
At the weſt port of the City, and defend there
My reputation, againſt all you meete,
For two houres on ly, i'l not ſweare Dinant,
To ſatisfie, (though ſure I thinke I ſhall)
What ever you deſire, if you denie this
Be deſperate, for willingly, by this light,
I'l never ſee thee more

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Two houres, doe you ſay?

sp.speaker: Lamir.
sp.l: Only two houres,

sp.speaker: Dina.
sp.l: I were no Gentleman,
Should I make ſcruple of it; this favour armes me,
And boldly il' performe it. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lamir.
sp.l: I am glad on't.
This will prevent their meeting yet, and keepe
My Brother ſafe, which was the marke I ſhott at. Exeunt.

div.head: Scena Prima.
div.stage: Enter Cleremont, as in the field.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I am firſt i'th field that honours gain'd of our ſide
Pray Heaven I may get of as honourablie,
The houre is paſt, I wonder Dinant comes not,
This is the place, I cannot ſee him yet;
It is his quarrell too, that brought me hither,
And I ne'r knew him yet, but to this honour,
A firme and worthy Friend, yet I ſee nothing,
Nor Horſe nor man; 'twould vex me, to be left here,
To th mercy of two ſwords, and two approved ones
I never knew him laſt.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: You are well met Cleremont.

sp.speaker: Verdo.
sp.l: You are a faire Gentleman, & love your friend Sir
What are you ready the time has over tane us?

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: And this you know the place.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: No Dinant yet?

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: We come not now to argue, but to doe;
We waite you Sir,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Ther's no time paſt yet. Gentlemen,
We have day enough: i'ſt poſſible he comes not?
You ſee I am ready here, and doe but ſtay,
Till my Friend come, walke but a turne or two,
'Twill not be long.

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: We came to fight.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Yee ſhall fight Gentlemen,
And fight enough, but a ſhort turne or two
I thinke I ſee him, ſet up your watch, wee'l fight by it.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: That is not hee; we will not be deluded.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Am I bobd thus, pray take a pipe of tobacco?
Or ſing but ſome new ayre; by that time, Gentlemen—

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: Come draw your ſword, you know the cuſtome here Sir
Firſt come, firſt ſerv'd

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Though it be held a cuſtome,
And practiſed ſo, I doe not hold it honeſt;
What honour can you both win on me ſingle?

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: Yeild up you ſword then.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Yeild my Sword? that's Hebrew;
I'll be firſt cut a peices; hold but a while,
I'll take the next that comes,
You are an old Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Yes indeed am I, Sir,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: And weare no Sword?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I need none; Sir,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I would you did, and had one;
I want now ſuch a fooliſh courteſie
You ſee theſe Gentlemen;

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: You want a ſecond.
In good Faith Sir, I was never handſome at it,
I would you had my Son, but hee's in Italy,
A proper Gentleman; you may doe well gallants
If you quarrell be not capitall, to have more mercy,
The Gentleman may doe his Country —

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Now I beſeech you, Sir,
If you dare not fight, doe not ſtay to beg my pardon,
There lies your way.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Good morrow Gentlemen. Exit.

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: You ſee your fortune,
You had better yeild your ſword.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Pray yee ſtay a little
Upon mine honeſtie, you ſhall be fought with;
Well, Dinant, well, theſe weare ſwords and ſeeme brave fellowes
As you are Gentlemen, one of you ſupply me
I want a ſecond now to meete theſe gallants,
You know what honour is,

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Sir you muſt pardon us,
We goe about the ſame worke, you are ready for;
And muſt fight preſently, els we were your ſervants,

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: God ſpeed you and good day. Exit Gent.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Am I thus Colted?

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: Come either yeild —

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: As you are honeſt Gentlemen,
Stay but the next, and then i'll take my fortune,
And if I fight not like a man — Fy Dinant,
Cold now and treacherous,

sp.speaker: La Writ.
sp.l: I underſtand your cauſes.
Yours about corne, yours about pinnes and glaſſes,
Will you make me mad, have I not all the parcells?
And his Petition too, about Bell-founding?
Send in your witneſſes, what will you have me doe?
Will you have me break my heart? my brains are melted;
And tell your Maſter, as I am a gentleman,
His Cauſe ſhall be the firſt, commend me to your Miſtris,
And tell her, if there be an extraordinary feather,
And tall enough for her: I ſhall diſpatch you too,
I know your Cauſe, for tranſporting of Farthingales
Trouble me no more, I ſay, againe to you,
No more vexation: bid my wife ſend me ſome puddings;
I have a Cauſe to run through, requires puddings,
Puddings enough. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: God ſpeed you, ſir.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: Would he would take this fellow.

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: A rare Youth.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: If you be not haſtie, ſir.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Yes, I am haſtie,
Exceeding haſtie, ſir, I am going to the Parliament,
You underſtand this bag, if you have any buſineſſe
Depending there, be ſhort, and let me heare it,
And pay your Fees.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: 'Faith, ſir, I have a buſineſſe,
But it depends upon no Parliament.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: I have no skill in't then.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I muſt deſire you,
'Tis a Sword matter, ſir.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: I am no Cutler,
I am an Advocate, ſir.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: How the thing lookes?

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: When he brings him to fight.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Be not ſo haſtie,
You weare a good Sword.

sp.speaker: La-writ,
sp.l: I know not that,
I never drew it yet, or whether it be a Sword—

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I muſt entreat you try, ſir, and beare a part
Againſt theſe Gentlemen, I want a ſecond;
Yee ſeeme a man, and 'tis a noble office.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: I am a Lawyer, ſir, I am no fighter.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: You that breed quarrells, ſir, know beſt to ſatisfie.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: This is ſome ſport yet.

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: If this fellow ſhould fight.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: And for any thing I know, I am an arrant coward,
Doe not truſt me, I thinke I am a coward.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Try, try, you are miſtaken: walke on gentlemen,
The man ſhall follow preſently.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Are ye mad gentleman?
My buſineſſe is within this halfe houre,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: That's all one,
We'll diſpatch within this quarter, there in that bottome,
'Tis moſt convenient gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Well, we'll wait, ſir.

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: Why this will be a comick fight, you'll follow.

sp.speaker: La-w.
sp.p: As I am a true man, I cannot fight. Ex. Beaup. Verdone.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Away, away,
I know you can: I like your modeſty,
I know you will fight, and ſo fight, with ſuch mettall,
And with ſuch judgement, meet your enemies ſury;
I ſee it in your eye, ſir.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: I'le be hang'd then;
And I charge you, in the Kings name, name no more fighting.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I charge you in the Kings name play the man,
Which if you doe not quickly, I begin with you,
Ile make you dance, doe you ſee your fiddle ſticke?
Sweet Advocate thou ſhalt fight.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Stand farther gentleman.
Or I'le give you ſuch a duſt o'th' chapps—

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Spoke bravely,
And like thy ſelfe, a noble Advocate:
Come to thy tooles.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: I doe not ſay I'le fight.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I ſay thou ſhalt, and bravely.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: If I doe fight;
I ſay, if I doe, but doe not depend upon't,
And yet I have a fooliſh itch upon me,
What ſhall become of my Writings?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Let 'em ly by,
They will not run away, man.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: I may be kil'd too,
And where are all my cauſes then? my buſineſſe?
I will not fight, I cannot fight, my Cauſes—

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt fight, if thou hadſt a thouſand cauſes,
Thou art a man to fight for any cauſe,
And carry it with honour.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Hum I ſay you ſo? if I ſhould
Be ſuch a coxcombe to prove valiant now—

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I know thou art moſt valiant.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Doe you thinke ſo?
I am undone for ever, if it prove ſo,
I tell you that, my honeſt friend, for ever;
For I ſhall ne're leave quarrelling.
How long muſt we fight? for I cannot ſtay,
Nor will not ſtay, I have buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: We'll do't in a minute in a moment.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Here will I hang my bag then, it may ſave my belly,
I never lov'd cold iron there.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: You doe wiſely.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Help me to pluck my ſword out then, quickly, quickly,
'T has not ſeen Sun theſe ten yeares.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: How it grumbles?
This Sword is vengeance angry.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Now I'le put my hat up,
And ſay my prayers as I goe; away boy,
If I be kill'd, remember the little Lawyer. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: They are both come on, that may be a ſtubborne raſcall,
Take you that ground, Enter La-writ.
Ile ſtay here, fight bravely.

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: To't chearfully my boyes, you'll let's have faire play,
None of your foyning tricks.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Come forward Monſieur; Fight.
What haſt thou there? a pudding in thy belly?
I ſhall ſee what it holds.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Put your ſpoone home then:
Nay, ſince I muſt fight, have at you without wit, ſir:
God a mercy bagg.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Nothing but bumbaſt in yee?
The rogue winkes and fights.

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Now your ſine fencing, ſir: Beau. loſes his ſword, La. writ treads on it.
Stand off, thou dieſt on point elſe,
I have it, I have it: yet further off:
I have his Sword.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Then keep it, be ſure you keep it.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: I'le put it in my mouth elſe.
Stand further off yet, and ſtand quietly,
And looke another way, or I'le be with you.
Is this all? I'le undertake within theſe two dayes
To furniſh any Cutler in this Kingdome.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Pox, what a fortune's this? diſarm'd by a puppie?
A ſnaile? a dog?

sp.speaker: La-Writ.
sp.l: No more o'theſe words Gentleman,
Sweet gentleman no more, doe not provoke me,
Goe walk i'th' horſe faire; whiſtle gentleman,
What muſt I doe now?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Help me, I am almoſt breathleſſe.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: With all my heart there's a cold py for you, ſir.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Thou ſtrik'ſt me, foole.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Thou foole, ſtand further off then,
Deliver, deliver.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Hold faſt. He ſtrikes up the others heeles, and takes his Sword too.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: I never faile in't
There's twelve pence, go buy you two leaden Daggers,
Have I done well?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Moſt like a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: And we two baſely loſt.

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: 'Tis but a fortune,
We ſhall yet find an houre. Ex. Beau. Verdoone ſad.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I ſhall be glad on't.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Where's my cloake, and my trinkets?
Or will you ſight any longer, for a craſh or two?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I am your noble friend, ſir.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: It may be ſo.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: What honour ſhall I doe you,
For this great courteſie?

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: All I deſire of ye,
Is to take the quarrell to your ſelfe, and let me heare no more on't
I have no liking to't, 'tis a fooliſh matter,
And help me to put up my Sword.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Moſt willingly.
But I am bound to gratifie you, and I muſt not leave you.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: I tell you, I will not be gratified,
Nor I will heare no more on't: take the Swords too,
And doe not anger me but leave me quietly.
For the matter of honour, 'tis at your owne diſpoſure,
And ſo, and ſo,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: This is a moſt rare Lawyer:
I am ſure moſt valiant. Well Dinant as you ſatisfie me,
I ſay no more: I am loden like an Armorer. Exit. Cler.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: To be diſpatcht upon a ſleeveleſſe errand?
To leave my friend engag'd, mine honour tainted?
Theſe are trim things. I am ſet here like a Perdue,
To watch a fellow, that has wrong'd my Miſtris,
A ſcurvy fellow, that muſt paſſe this way,
But what this ſcurvy fellow is, or whence,
Or whether his name be William or John,
Or Anthony or Dick or any thing, I know not;
A ſcurvy raſcally fellow. I muſt aime at,
And there's the office of an Aſſe flung on me.
Sure Cleremont has fought, but how come off,
And what the world ſhall thinke of me hereafter:
Well, woman, woman. I muſt looke your raſcalls,
And looſe my reputation: ye have a fine power over us.
Theſe two long houres I have trotted here, and curiouſly
Survei'd all goers by, yet find no raſcall,
Nor any face to quarrell with: La-writ ſings within then Enters.
What's that?
This is a raſcally voice ſure it comes this way.

sp.speaker: La-writ.

l.hi: He ſtrooke ſo hard the Baſon broke,

sp.l: And Tarquin heard the ſound.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: What maſter thing is this? let me ſurvey it.

l.hi: And then he ſtrooke his necke in two.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: This may be a raſcall, but 'tis a mad raſcall,
What an Alphabet of faces he puts on?
Hey how it fences? if this ſhould be the rogue,
As 'tis the likelieſt rogue. I ſee this day—

l.hi: Was ever man for Ladies ſake? down, down.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: And what are you good ſir? down, down, down, down.

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: What's that to you, good ſir? downe, downe.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: A pox on you good, ſir, downe, downe, downe,
You with your Buckram bag, what make you here?
And from whence come you? I could fight with my ſhadow now.

sp.speaker: La-w.
sp.l: Thou fierce man, that like ſir Lancelot doſt appear,
I need not tell thee what I am, nor eke what I make here.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: This is a pretious knave, ſtay, ſtay, good Triſtram,
And let me aske thy mightineſſe a queſtion,
Did ye never abuſe a Lady?

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Not; to abuſe a Lady, is very hard, ſir,

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Say you ſo, ſir?
Didſt thou never abuſe her honour?

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Not; to abuſe her honour, is impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Certaine this is the raſcall: What's thy name?

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: My name is Cock a two, uſe me reſpectively,
I will be Cocke of three elſe.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: What's all this?
You ſay, you did abuſe a Lady;

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: You ly.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: And that you wrong'd her honour.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: That's two lyes,
Speake ſuddenly, for I am full of buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: What art thou, or what canſt thou be, thou peagooſe,
That dar'ſt give me the ly thus? thou mak'ſt me wonder.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: And wonder on, till time makes all this plaine.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: You muſt not part ſo, ſir, art thou a gentleman?

sp.speaker: La-w.
sp.l: Aske thoſe, upon whoſe ruines, I am mounted.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: This is ſome Cavellero Knight o'th'Sun.

sp.speaker: La-w.
sp.l: I tell thee, I am as good a gentleman as the Duke;
I have atchieved — goe follow thy buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: But for this Lady, ſir—

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Why, hang this Lady, ſir,
And the Lady Mother too, ſir, what have I to do with Ladies?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: 'Tis the little Lawyers voice: has he got my way?
It ſhould be here abouts.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Ye dry bisket rogue,
I wil ſo ſwinge you for this blaſphemie—
Have I found you out?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: That ſhould be Dinants tongue too.

sp.speaker: La-w.
sp.l: And I defy thee, do thy worſt: ô ho quoth Lancelot tho.
And that thou ſhalt know, I am a true gentleman,
And ſpeake according to the phraſe triumphant;
Thy Lady, is a ſcurvy Lady, and a ſhitten Lady,
And though I never heard of her, a deboſhed Lady,
And thou, a ſquire of low degree; will that content thee?
Doſt thou way-lay me with Ladies? A pretty ſword, ſir,
A very pretty ſword, I haue a great mind to't.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: You ſhall not looſe your longing, rogue.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Hold, hold,
Hold Dinant, as thou art a gentleman.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: As much as you will, my hand is in now.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I am your friend, ſir: Dinant you draw your ſword
Upon the gentleman, preſerv'd your honour:
This was my ſecond and did back me nobly,
For ſhame forbeare.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I aske your mercy, ſir, and am your ſervant now.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: May we not fight then?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I am ſure you ſhall not now.

sp.speaker: La-w.
sp.l: I am ſorry for't I am ſure I'le ſtay no longer then.
Not a jot longer: are there any more on ye afore?
I will ſing ſtill, ſir. Exit La-writ,

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I looke now you ſhould chide me, and 'Tis ſir,
And with much bitterneſſe, expreſſe your anger,
I have deſerv,d: yet when you know—.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I thanke ye,
Doe you thinke, that the wrong you have offred me,
The moſt unmanly wrong, unfriendly wrong—

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I doe confeſſe —

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: That boyiſh ſleight—

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Not ſo, ſir.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: That poore, and baſe renouncing of your honour,
Can be allaied with words?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I give you way ſtill.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Coloured with ſmooth excuſes? Was it a friends part,
A Gentlemans, a mans that weares a Sword,
And ſtands upon the point of reputation,
To hide his head, then, when his honour call'd him?
Call'd him alowd, and lead him to his fortune?
To halt and ſlip the coller? by my life,
I would have given my life, I had never knowne thee,
Thou haſt eaten Canker-like into my judgement
With this diſgrace, my whole life, cannot heale agiine.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: This I can ſuffer too, I find it honeſt.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Can you pretend an excuſe now may abſolve you,
Or any thing like honeſt, to bring you off?
Ingage me like an Aſſe?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Will you but heare me?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Expoſe me like a Jade, to tug, and hale through,
Laugh'd at, and almoſt hooted? your diſgraces,
Invite mens Swords, and angers to diſpatch me.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: If you will be patient.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: And be abus'd ſtill: But that I have call'd thee friend,
And to that name, allow a Sanctuary,
You ſhould heare further from me, I would not talk thus:
But henceforth ſtand upon your owne bottome, ſir,
And beare your owne abuſes, I ſcorne my ſword
Should travell in ſo poore and empty quarrells.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Ha, you done yet? take your whole ſwinge of anger,
I'le beare all with content.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Why were you abſent?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: You know I am no Coward, you have ſeene that,
And therefore, out of feare, forſooke you not:
You know I am not falſe, of a treacherous nature,
Apt to betray my friend I have fought for you too;
You know no buſineſſe, that concern'd my ſtate,
My kindred, or my life.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Where was the fault then?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: The honour of that Lady I adore
Her credit, and her name: ye know ſhe ſent for me,
And with what haſt.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: What was he that traduc'd?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: The man i'th' Moone, I think, hither I was ſent,
But to what end—

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: This is a pretty flim-flam.

sp.speaker: O. La.
sp.l: I am glad I have met you ſir, I have bin ſeeking,
And ſeeking every where.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: And now you have found him,
Declare that buſineſſe, our Embaſſadour.

sp.speaker: O. Lady.
sp.l: What's that to ye good man flouter? O ſir, my Lady.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Prethee no more of thy Lady, I have too much on't.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Let me have a little, ſpeake to me.

sp.speaker: Old Lady.
sp.l: To you ſir?
'Tis more then time: All occaſions ſet aſide ſir,
Or whatſoever may be thought a buſineſſe—

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Old Lady.
sp.l: Repaire to me within this houre.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: O. Lady.
sp.l: What's that to you? come you, ſir, when y'are ſent for.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: God a mercy Mumpſimus,
You may goe Dinant, and follow this old Fairie,
Till you have loſt your ſelfe, your friends, your credit,
And hunny out your youth, in rare adventures,
I can but grieve, I have knowne you.

sp.speaker: Old Lady.
sp.l: Will ye goe ſir?
I come not often to you with theſe bleſſings,
You may believe that thing there, and repent it,
That dogged thing,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Peace touchwood.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I will not goe:
Goe bid your Lady ſeeke ſome foole, to fawne on her
Some unexperienc'd puppie, to make ſport with,
I have bin her mirth too long, thus I ſhake from me
The fetters ſhe put on; thus her enchantments
I blow away like wind, no more her beauty.

sp.speaker: Old Lady.
sp.l: Take heed ſir, what you ſay.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Goe forward, Dinant.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: The charmes ſhot from her eyes —

sp.speaker: O. Lady.
sp.l: Be wiſe.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Be Valiant.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: That tongue that tells faire tales to mens deſtructions
Shall never rack me more.

sp.speaker: Old Lady.
sp.l: Stay there.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Goe forward.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I will now heare her, ſee her as a woman,
Survey her and the power man has allowed, ſir,
As I would doe the courſe of common things,
Unmov'd, unſtruck.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Hold there, and I forgive thee.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: She is not faire, and that that makes her proud,
Is not her owne, our eies beſtow it on her,
To touch and kiſſe he●, is no bleſſedneſſe,
A Sun-burnt Ethiopes lip's as ſoft as hers.
Goe bid her ſtick ſome other triumph up,
And take into her favour ſome dull foole,
That has no pretious time to looſe, no friends,
No honour, nor no life, like a bold Merchant,
A bold and banquerupt man, I have ventur'd all theſe,
And ſplit my bottome: returne this anſwer to her,
I am awake againe, and ſee her miſchiefes,
And am not now, on every idle errand,
And now coyn'd anger, to be hurried,
And then deſpis'd againe, I have forgot her.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: If this be true—

sp.speaker: O. Lady.
sp.l: I am ſorry, I have troubled you,
More ſorrie, that my Lady has adventur'd
So great a favour, in ſo weake a mind:
This houre you have refus'd, that when you come to know it,
Will run you mad, and make you curſe that fellow,
She is not faire, nor handſome, ſo I leave you.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Stay Lady, ſtay, but is there ſuch a buſineſſe?

sp.speaker: O. Lady.
sp.l: You would breake your neck 'twere yours.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: My back, you would ſay.

sp.speaker: O. La.
sp.l: But play the friends part ſtill, ſir, and undoe him,
'Tis a faire office.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I have ſpoke too liberally.

sp.speaker: O. Lady.
sp.l: I ſhall deliver what you ſay.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: You ſhall be hang'd firſt,
You would faine be prating now; take the man with you.

sp.speaker: O. Lady.
sp.l: Not I, I have no power.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: You may goe Dinant.

sp.speaker: O. Lady.
sp.l: 'Tis in's own will, I had no further charge, ſir,
Then to tell him what I did, which if I had thought
It ſhould have bin receiv'd ſo—

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: 'Faith you may,
You doe not know, how far it may concerne you.
If I perceiv'd any trick in't.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: 'Twill end there.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: 'Tis my fault then, there is an houre in fortune,
That muſt be ſtill obſerv'd: you thinke I'll chide you,
When things muſt be, nay ſee, an he will hold his head up?
Would ſuch a Lady ſend with ſuch a charge too?
Say ſhe has plaid the foole, play the foole with her againe,
The great foole, the greater ſtill the better,
He ſhall goe with you woman.

sp.speaker: Old Lady.
sp.l: As it pleaſe him,
I know the way alone elſe.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Where is your Lady?

sp.speaker: O. Lady.
sp.l: I ſhall direct you quickly.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Well, I'll goe,
But what her wrongs, will give me leave to ſay.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: We'll leave that to your ſelves: I ſhall heare from you.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: As ſoone as I come off—

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Come on then bravely;
Farewell till then, and play the man.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: You are merry;
All I expect is ſcorne: Ile lead you Lady.

div.head: Scena prima.
div.stage: Enter Champernell, Lamira, Beaupre, Verdoone, Chailote.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: We'll venture on him.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Out of my dores I charge thee, ſee me no more.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Your Nephew?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: I diſclaime him.
He has no part in me, nor in my blood,
My Brother that kept fortune bound, and left
Conqueſt hereditary to his Iſſue
Could not beget a coward.

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: I fought, ſir,
Like a good fellow, and a ſouldier too,
But men are men, and cannot make their fates:
Aſcribe you to my Father, what you pleaſe,
I am borne to ſuffer.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: All diſgrace: wretch.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Good ſir be patient.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Was there no tree,
(For to fall by a noble enemies ſword,
A Coward is unworthy) nor no River,
To force thy life out backward, or to drowne it,
But that thou muſt ſurvive thy infamie?
And kill me, with the ſight of one I hate?
And gladly would forget?

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: Sir, his misfortune
Deſerves not this reproofe.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: In your opinion,
'Tis fit you two ſhould be of one beliefe,
You are indeed, fine gallants, and fight bravely
I'th' City with your tongues, but in the field
Have neither ſpirit to dare, nor power to doe,
Your ſwords, are all ledd there.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: I know no duty,
(How ever you may wreake your ſpleene on him)
That bindes me to endure this.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: From Dinant
You'll ſuffer more; that ever curſed I,
Should give my honour up, to the defence
Of ſuch a thing as he is, or my Lady
That is all Innocent, for whom a dove would
Aſſume the courage of a daring Eagle,
Repoſe her confidence in one that can
No better guard her. In contempt of you
I love Dinant, mine enemy, nay admire him,
His valour claimes it from me, and with juſtice,
He that could fight thus, in a cauſe not honeſt,
His ſword edg'd with defence, of right and honour,
Would pierce as deep as lightning, with that ſpeed too,
And kill as deadly.

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: You are as far from Juſtice,
In him you praiſe, as equitie in the cenſure,
You load me with.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: Dinant? he durſt not meet us.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: How? durſt not brother?

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: Durſt not, I repeat it;

sp.speaker: Verdo.
sp.l: Nor was it Cleremont's valour that diſarm'd us,
I had the better of him; for Dinant,
If that might make my peace with you, I dare
Write him a Coward, upon every poſt,
And with the hazard of my life defend it.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: If 'twere laied at the ſtake, you'd looſe it, Nephew.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Came he not, ſay you?

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: No, but in his roome,
There was a divell, hir'd from ſome Magician
I'th' ſhape of an Atturney.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: 'Twas he did it.

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: And his the honour.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: I could wiſh Dinant—
But what talke I of one that ſtept aſide,
And durſt not come?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I am ſuch a friend to truth,
I cannot heare this: why doe you detract
Thus poorely (I ſhould ſay to others baſely)
From one, of ſuch approv'd worth?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Ha! how's this?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: From one ſo excellent, in all that's noble,
Whoſe onely weakneſſe, is exceſſe of courage?
That knowes no enemies, that he cannot maſter,
But his affections, and in them, the worſt
His love to me.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: To you?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Yes, ſir to me,
I dare (for what is that, which Innocence dares not)
To you profeſſe it, and he ſhun'd the Combat
For feare, or doubt of theſe: bluſh and repent,
That you in thought, ere did that wrong to valour.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Why, this is rare.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: 'Fore heaven, exceeding rare;
Why modeſt Lady, you that ſing ſuch Encomiums
Of your firſt Suiter—

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: How can ye convince us
In our reports?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: VVith what you cannot anſwer,
'Twas my command that ſtaied him.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Your command?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Mine, ſir, and had my will rank'd with my power,
And his obedience, I could have ſent him
VVith more eaſe, weaponleſſe to you, and bound,
Then have kept him back, ſo well he loves his honour
Beyond his life.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Better, and better ſtill,

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I wrought with him in private to divert him
From your aſſur'd deſtruction, had he met you.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: In private?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Yes, and us'd all Arts, all Charmes,
Of one that knew her ſelfe the abſolute Miſtris
Of all his faculties.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Gave all rewards too
His ſervice could deſerve; did not he take
The meaſure of my ſheets?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Doe not looke yellow,
I have cauſe to ſpeake; frownes cannot fright me,
By all my hopes, as I am ſpotleſſe to you,
If I reſt once aſſur'd, you doe but doubt me,
Or curbe me of that freedome, you once gave me—

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: VVhat then?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I'll not alone, abuſe your bed, that's nothing,
But to your more vexation, 'tis reſov'd on,
I'll run away, and then try if Dinant
Have courage to defend me.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Impudent!

sp.speaker: Verdo.
sp.l: And on the ſudden—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: How are ye transform'd,
From what you were?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I was an innocent Virgin,
And I can truly ſweare, a Wife as pure
As ever lay by Husband, and will dy ſo,
Let me live unſuſpected, I am no ſervant,
Nor will be us'd like one: If you deſire
To keep me conſtant, as I would be, let
Truſt and beliefe in you, beget, and nurſe it;
Unneceſſary jealouſies, make more whores
Then all baites els, laied to entrap our frailties.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: There's no conteſting with her, from a child
Once mov'd, ſhe hardly was to be appeas'd,
Yet I dare ſweare her honeſt.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: So I thinke too,
On better judgement: I am no Italian
To lock her up; nor would I be a Dutchman,
To have my Wife, my ſoveraigne, to command me:
I'll try the gentler way, but if that faile,
Believe it, Sir, there's nothing but extreames,
VVhich ſhe muſt feele from me.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: That, as you pleaſe, ſir.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: You have won the breeches, Madam, looke up ſweetly,
My Lord limpes toward you.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: You will learne more manners.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: This is a fee, for counſell that's unask'd for.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Come, I miſtook thee ſweet, prethee forgive me,
I never will be jealous: ere I cheriſh
Such a mechanick humour; I'll be nothing;
I'll ſay Dinant, is all that thou wouldſt have him,
VVill that ſuffice?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: 'Tis well, ſir.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Uſe thy freedome
Uncheck'd, and unobſerv'd, if thou wilt have it,
Theſe ſhall forget their honour, I my wrongs
We'll all dote on him, hell be my reward
If I diſſemble.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: And that hell take me
If I affect him, he's a luſtfull villaine,
(But yet no coward) and ſollicites me
To my diſhonour, that's indeed a quarrell,
And truly mine, which I will ſo revenge,
As it ſhall fright, ſuch as dare onely thinke
To be adulterers.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Uſe thine owne waies,
I give up all to thee.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: O women, women!
When you are pleas'd you are the leaſt of evils.

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: I'll rime to't, but provokt, the worſt of divells.

div.stage: Enter Monſier Sampſon, and three Clients.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.l: I know Monſier La-writ.

sp.speaker: 1 Cly.
sp.l: VVould he knew himſelfe, Sir.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.l: He was a pretty Lawyer, a kind of pretty Lawyer.
Of a kind, of unable thing.

sp.speaker: 2 Cly.
sp.l: A fine Lawyer, Sir,
And would have firk'd you up a buſineſſe,
And out of this Court into that.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.l: Ye are too forward,
Not ſo fine my friends, ſomething he could have done,
But ſhort, ſhort.

sp.speaker: 1 Cly.
sp.l: I know your worſhips favour,
You are Nephew to the Judge, Sir.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.l: It may be ſo,
And ſomething may be done, without trotting i'th' durt, friends;
It may be I can take him in his Chamber,
And have an houres talke, it may be ſo,
And tell him that in's eare, there are ſuch courteſies:
I will not ſay, I can.

sp.speaker: 3 Cly.
sp.l: VVe know you can, ſir.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Peradventure I, peradventure no: but where's Lawrit?
VVhere's your ſufficient Lawyer?

sp.speaker: 1 Cly.
sp.l: He's blowne up, Sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Cly.
sp.l: Run mad, and quarrells, with the dog he meets;
He is no Lawyer, of this world now.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.l: Your reaſon?
Is he defunct? is he dead?

sp.speaker: 2 Cly.
sp.l: No, he's not dead yet, ſir;
But I would be loth to take a leaſe on's life for two houres:
Alas, he is poſſeſt ſir, with the ſpirit of fighting,
And quarrells with all people; but how he came to it—

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.l: If he fight well, and like a Gentleman,
The man may fight, for 'tis a lawfull calling.
Looke you my friends, I am a civill Gentleman,
And my Lord my Uncle loves me.

sp.speaker: 3 Cly.
sp.l: We all know it, ſir.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: I thinke he does, ſir, I have buſineſs too, much buſineſſe,
Turn you ſome forty or fifty Cauſes in a weeke;
Yet when I get an houre of vacancie,
I can fight too my friends, a little does well,
I would be loth to learne to fight.

sp.speaker: 1 Cly.
sp.l: But and't pleaſe you, ſir,
His fighting has neglected all our buſineſſe,
We are undone, our cauſes caſt away, ſir,
His not appearance.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: There he fought too long
A little, & fight well, he fought too long indeed friends;
But ne'r the leſſe, things muſt be, as they may,
And there be wayes—

sp.speaker: 1 Cly.
sp.l: We know, ſir, if you pleaſe—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Something I'll doe; goe rally up your Cauſes.

div.stage: Enter La-writ, and a Gentleman at the dore.

sp.speaker: 2 Cly.
sp.l: Now you may behold ſir,
And be a witneſſe, whether we lie or no.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: I'll meet you at the Ordinary, ſweet Gentlemen,
And if there be a wench or two—

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: We'll have 'em.

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: No handling any Duells before I come,
We'll have no going leſſe, I hate a coward.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: There ſhall be nothing done.

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Make all the quarrells
You can deviſe before I come, and let's all fight,
There is no ſport els.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: We'll ſee what may be done, ſir,

sp.speaker: 1 Cly.
sp.l: Ha? Monſier La-writ?

sp.speaker: La-Wr.
sp.l: Baffled in way of buſineſſe,
My cauſes caſt away, Judgement againſt us?
Why there it goes

sp.speaker: 2 Cli.
sp.l: What ſhall we do the whilſt Sir?

sp.speaker: La-Wr.
sp.l: Breed new diſſentions, goe hang your ſelves
'Tis allo ne to me; I have a new trade of living.

sp.speaker: 1 Cli.
sp.l: Doe you heare what he ſaies Sir?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: The Gentleman, ſpeakes finely

sp.speaker: La Wr.
sp.l: Will any of you fight? Fightings my occupation
If you find your ſelves agreev'd;

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: A compleate Gentleman.

sp.speaker: La-Wr.
sp.l: Avant thou buckr●m budget of petitions,
Thou ſpittle of lame cauſes; I lament for thee,
And till revenge be taken —

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: 'Tis moſt excellent.

sp.speaker: La-Wr.
sp.l: There every man chuſe his paper, and his place.
I'll anſwer ye all, I will neglect no mans buſines
But he ſhall have ſatisfaction like a Gentleman,
The Judge may doe and not doe, hee's but a Monſieur

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: You have nothing of mine in your bag, Sir,

sp.speaker: La-Wr.
sp.l: I know not Sir,
But you may put any thing in, any fighting thing

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: It is ſufficient, you may heare hereafter.

sp.speaker: La-Wr.
sp.l: I reſt your ſervant Sir,

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: No more words Gentlemen
But follow me, no more words as you love me,
The Gentlemans, a noble Gentleman.
I ſhall doe what I can, and then —

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: We thanke you Sir, Exit Sam. and Clients.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Not a word to diſturb him, hee's a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: La-Wr.
sp.l: No cauſe goe? o my ſide the judge caſt all?
And becauſe I was honourably employed in action,
And not appear'd, pronounce? 'tis very well,
'Tis well faith, 'tis well, Judge.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Who have we here?
My little furious Lawyer?

sp.speaker: La-Wr.
sp.l: I ſay 'tis well,
But marke the end.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: How he is metamorphis'd?
Nothing of Lawyer left not a bit of buckrum,
No ſolliciting face now,
This is no ſimple converſion
Your ſervant Sir, and Friend.

sp.speaker: La-Wr.
sp.l: You come in time, Sir,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: The happier man, to be at your command then.

sp.speaker: La-Wr.
sp.l: You may wonder to ſee me thus; but tha'ts all one
Time ſhall declare; 'tis true I was a Lawyer,
But I have mend that coat, I hate a Lawyer,
I talk'd much in the Court, now I hate talking
I did you the office of a man.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I muſt confeſſe it,

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: And budg'd not, no I budg'd not

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: No, ye did not,

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Ther's it then, one good turne requires another

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Moſt willing Sir, I am ready at your ſervice

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: There read, and underſtand, & then deliver it

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: This is a challenge Sir,

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: 'Tis very like Sir,
I ſeldome now write Sonnets

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: To Monſieur Vertaigne the preſident,

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: I chooſe no foole ſir,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Why hee's no ſword man Sir,

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Let him learne, let him learne,
Time that traines Chickens up, will teach him quickly

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Why hee's a Judge, an old man.

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Never too old.
To be a Gentleman; and he that is a judge
Can judge beſt what belongs to wounded honour;
There are my griefes he has caſt away my cauſes,
In which he has bowed my reputation.
And therefore Judge, or no Judge,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Pray be rul'd Sir,
This is the maddeſt thing —

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: You will not carry it,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I doe not tell you ſo, but if you may be perſwaded

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: You know how you us'd me, when I would not fight,
Doe you remember Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: The Divells in him.

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: I ſee it in your eyes, that you dare it
You have a carrying face, and you ſhall carry it,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: The leaſt is baniſhment

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Be baniſh'd then;
'Tis a friends part, wee'll meete in Africa,
Or any corner of the earth.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Say he will not fight,

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: I know then what to ſay take you no care Sir,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Well, I will carry it, and deliver it,
And to morrow morning meete you in the louer,
Till when, my ſervice,

sp.speaker: La-Wr.
sp.l: A Judge, or no Judge, no Judge. Exit La-wr.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: This is the prettieſt Rogue that 'ere I read of,
None to provoke tot'h field, but the old preſident;
What face ſhall I put on? if I come in earneſt,
I am ſure to weare a paire of braceletts;
This may make ſome ſport yet, I will deliver it
Here comes the preſident.

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: I ſhall find time Gentlemen,
To doe your cauſes good, is not that Cleremont.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: 'Tis he my Lord?

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: Why does he ſmile upon me?
Am I become ridiculous? has your fortune Sir
Upon my ſon made you contemne his Father?
The glory of a Gentleman, is faire bearing,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Miſtake me not my Lord, you ſhall not find that;
I come with no blowen ſpirit to abuſe you,
I know your place, and honour due unto it,
The reverence to your ſilver age and vertue,

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: Your face is merry ſtill.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: So is my buſſineſſe,
And I beſeech your honour, miſtake me not
I have brought you from a wild, or rather mad man
As mad a peice — of you were wont to love mirth,
In your young dayes, I have knowne your honour wo it
This may be made no little one, 'tis a challenge Sir,
Nay ſtart not I beſeech you, it meanes you no harme
Nor any man of honour, or underſtanding
'Tis to ſteale from your ſerious houres a little laughters
I am bold to bring it to your Lordſhip,

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: 'Tis to me indeed.
Doe they take me for a ſword man, at theſe yeares?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: 'Tis onely worth your honours mirth thats all Sir,
'Tad bin in me elſe a ſawcie rudeneſſe.

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: From one La-Writ, a very punctuall challenge,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: But if your Lordſhip marke it, no great matter

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: I have knowne ſuch a wrangling advocate,
Such a little figent thiing; Oh I remember him,
A notable talking knave, now out upon him,
Has challeng'd me downe right, defied me mortally
I doe remember too, I caſt his cauſes

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Why ther's the quarrell Sir, the mortall quarrell

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: Why what a knave is this? as y'are? Gentleman
Is there no further purpoſe but meere mirth?
What a bold man of warre, he invites me roundly

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: If there ſhould be, I were no Gentleman.
Nor worthy of the honour of my kindred,
And though I am ſure your Lordſhip hate my perſon,
Which time may bring againe into your favour,
Yet for my manners —

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: I am ſatisfied,
You ſee Sir, I have out li'v'd thoſe daies of fighting,
And therfore cannot do him the honour to beate him my ſelfe
But I have a kinsman, much of his abilitie
His wit and carriage, for this calls him foole,
One that will ſpit as ſenſeleſſe fire, as this fellow

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: And ſuch a man to undertake, my Lord,

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Nay hees too forward, theſe two pitch barrells together

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Upon my ſoule no harme.

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: It makes me ſmile,
Why what a ſtinking ſmother will they utter?
Yes he ſhall undertake Sir, as my Champion,
Since you propound it mirth, i'll venture on it
And ſhall defend my cauſe, but as y'ar honeſt
Sport not with blood.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Thinke not ſo baſely, good Sir,

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: A ſquire ſhall waite upon you from my kinsman,
To morrow morning, make your ſport at full,
You want no ſubject, but no wounds.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: That's my care

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.p: And ſo good day. Exit Vertaine and Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Many unto your honour,
This is a noble fellow of a ſweet ſpirit,
Now muſt I thinke how to contrive this matter,
For together they ſhall goe. Enter Dinant.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: O Cleremont
I am glad I have found thee,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I can tell thee rare things,

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: O I can tell thee rarer,
Doſt thou love me?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Love thee?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Doeſt thou love me dearely
Dar'ſt thou for my ſake?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Any thing that's honeſt

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Though it be dangerous

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Pox o dangerous

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Nay wonderous dangerous.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Wilt thou breake my hearte?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Along with me then.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I muſt part to morrow.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: You ſhall, you ſhall, be faithfull for this night
And thou haſt made thy freind.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: O Nurſe welcome, where's Dinant?

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: Hee is at my back
'Tis the moſt liberall Gentleman, this gold,
He gave me for my paines, nor can I blame you,
If you yeild up the for't

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: How? yeild it up?

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: I know not, he that loves, and gives ſo largely,
And a young Lord to boote, or I am couſend
May enter every where,

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Thou't make me angry.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: Why if you are I hope heres on will pleaſe you,
Looke on him with my eyes, good luck goe with you
Were I young for your ſake. —

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I thanke thee Nurſe,

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: I would be tractable, and as I am —

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Leave the roome,
So old, and ſo immodeſt? and be carefull,
Since whiſpers will make ſleeping jealouſies.
That none diſturb my Lord. Exit Nurſe.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Will you diſpatch?
Till you come to the matter be not rapt thus,
Walk in, walk in, I am your ſcout for once,
You owe me the like ſervice,

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: And will pay it,

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: As you reſpect our lives, ſpeake not ſo loud

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Why, to it in dumb ſhew then, I am ſilenc'd

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Be not ſo haſty Sir, the golden apples,
Had a fell dragon for their guard, your pleaſures
Are to be attempted with Herculean danger,
Or never to be gotten

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Speake the meanes,

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Thus briefely my Lord ſleepes now, and alas,
Each night he only ſleepes.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Goe keepe her ſtirring,

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Now if he wake, as ſometimes he does,
He only ſtretches out his hand and feeles,
Whether I am a bed, which being aſſur'd of
He ſleepes againe; But ſhould he miſſe me, valour
Could not defend our lives,

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Wha'ts to be done then?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Servants have ſervile Faiths, nor have I any
That I dare truſt; on noble Cleremont
We ſafely may rely

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: What man can doe,
Command and boldly,

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Thus then in my place,
You muſt lye with my Lord,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: With an old man?
Two beards together? that's prepoſtrous.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: There is no other way, and though 'tis dangerous
He having ſervants within call; and arm'd too,
Slaves feed to act, all that his jealouſy,
And rage commands them, yet a true friend ſhould not
Checke at the hazard of a life,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I thanke you,
I love my friend, but know no reaſon why
To hate my ſelf, to be a kind of pander,
You ſee I am willing,
But to betray mine owne throat you muſt pardon,

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Then I am loſt, and all my hopes defeated
Were I to hazard ten times more for you,
You ſhould find, Cleremont —

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: You ſhall not out doe me,
Fall what may fall, i'll do't

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: But for his beard —

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: To cover that you ſhall have my night Linnen,
And you diſpos'd of, my Dinant and I,
Will have ſome private conference.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Private doing,
Or i'll not venture,

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: That's as we agree. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Nurſe and Charloth, paſs 'ore the ſtage with pillowes night Cloaths and ſuch things.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: What can this Woman do, preſerving her honour?
I have given her all the liberty that may be
I will not be far off though; nor I will not be jealous
Nor truſt too much, I think ſhe is vertuous,
Yet when I hold her beſt, ſhe's but a woman,
As full of frailty as of Faith, a poore ſleight woman,
And her beſt thoughts, but weake fortifications,
There may be a meane wrought. Well, let'em work then,
I ſhall meet with it: till the ſignes be monſtrous,
And ſtick upon my head, I will not believe it, Stands pri|vate.
She may be & ſhe may not: now to my obſervation.

sp.speaker: Din:
sp.l: VVhy do you make me ſtay ſo? if you love me—

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: You are too hot, and violent.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Why doe you ſhift thus
From one chamber to another?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: A little delay, ſir,
Like fire, a little ſprinckled ore with water,
Makes the deſires burne c●eare, and ten times hotter.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Why doe you ſpeake ſo lowd? I pray'e goe in
Sweet Miſtris I am mad, time ſteales away,
And when we would enjoy—.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Now fy, fy ſervant, Wine.
Like ſenſuall beaſts, ſhall we enjoy our pleaſures?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Pray doe but kiſſe me then.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Why, that I will, and you ſhall find anon, ſervant.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: oftly for heavens ſake, you know my friend's engag'd,
A little now, now; Will you goe in againe?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Why doe you laugh ſo lowd? pretious,
Will you betray me? ha my friends throat cut?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Come, come, I'le kiſſe thee again.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Will you ſo? you are liberall,
If you doe cozen me —

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: What's this?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Wine, wine, a draught or two.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: What does this woman here?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: She ſhall not hinder you.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: This might have bin ſpar'd,
'Tis but delay, and time loſt: pray ſend her ſoftly off.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Sit downe, and mix your ſpirits with VVine,
I will make you another Hercules.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I dare not drinke;
Fy, what delayes you make? I dare not, Recorders.
I ſhall be drunke preſently and do ſtrange things then.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Not drink a cup with your Miſtris? ô the pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Lady, why this? Muſicke.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: We muſt have mirth to our wine, man.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Pl— o'th' Muſick.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: God-a-mercy VVench,
If thou doſt Cuckold me, I ſhall forgive thee.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: The houſe will all riſe now, this will diſturb all.
Did you doe this?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Peace, and ſit quiet, foole,
You love me, come, ſit downe and drinke.

sp.speaker: Cler,
sp.l: VVhat a divell aile you?
How cold I ſweat? a hogs pox, ſtop your pipes, Muſick.
The thing will wake: now, now me thinks I find
His Sword juſt gliding through my throte: VVhat's that?
A vengeance choke your pipes. Are you there Lady?
Stop, ſtop thoſe raſcalls; doe you bring me hither
To be cut into minced meate? VVhy Dinant?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I cannot doe withall;
I have ſpoke, and ſpoke: I am betraied, and loſt too.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Doe you heare me? do you underſtand me?
Plague dam your whiſtles. Muſicke ends.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: 'Twas but an over-ſight, they have done, ly down.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: VVould you had done too.
You know not
In what a miſery, and feare I ly.
You have a Lady in your armes.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I would have— The Recorders againe.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: I'le watch you, goodman wood have.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Remove for heavens ſake,
And fall to that you come for.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Ly you downe,
'Tis but an houres endurance now.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I dare not, ſoftly ſweet Lady,—heart?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: 'Tis nothing but your feare, he ſleeps ſtill ſoundly,
Ly gently downe.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: 'Pray make an end.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Come, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Theſe Chambers are too neare. Ex. Din. Lam.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: I ſhall be nearer;
Well, goe thy wayes. I'le truſt thee through the world,
Deale how thou wilt: that that I never feele,
