I'le never feare. Yet by the honour of a Souldiour,
I hold thee truly Noble. How theſe things will looke,
And how their bloods will curdle? play on children,
You ſhall have pap anon. O thou grand foole,
That thou knoweſt, but thy fortune — Muſick done.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Peace, good Madam,
Stop her mouth Dinant, it ſleeps yet, 'pray' be wary,
Diſpatch, I cannot endure this miſery,
I can heare nothing more; I'le ſay my praiers,
And downe againe— Whiſtle within.
A thouſand larums, fall upon my quarter,
Heaven ſend me off; When I ly keeping courſes.
Pl— o' your fumbling Dinant; how I ſhake?
'Tis ſtill againe. Would I were in the Indies. Exit Cler.

div.stage: Enter Dinant, and Lamira. A light within.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Why doe ye uſe me thus? thus poorely? baſely?
Worke me into a hope, and then deſtroy me?
Why did you ſend for me? this new way traine me?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Madman, a fool, & falſ man, now Ile ſhew thee man

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: 'Pray' put your light out.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: No I'le hold it thus,
That all chaſt eyes, may ſee thy luſt, and ſcorne it,
Tell me but this, when you firſt doted on me,
And made ſuite to enjoy me, as your wife,
Did you not hold me honeſt?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Yes, moſt vertuous.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: And did not that appeare, the onely luſtre
That made me worth your love, and admiration?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I muſt confeſſe—

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Why would you deale ſo baſely?
So like a thiefe? a villaine?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Peace, good Madam.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I'le ſpeake aloud too; thus maliciouſly,
Thus breaking all the rules of honeſtie,
Of honour, and of truth, for which I lov'd you,
For which, I call'd you ſervant, and admir'd you,
To ſteale that jewell, purchas'd by another
Piouſly ſet in Wedlock, even that Jewell,
Becauſe it had no flame, you held unvaluable:
Can he that has lov'd good, doat on the divell?
For he that ſeekes a whore, ſeeks but his agent:
Or am I of ſo wild, and low of blood,
So nurs'd in infamies?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I doe not thinke ſo,
And I repent.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: That will not ſerve your turne, ſir.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: It was your treaty drew me on.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: But it was your villany,
Made you purſue it: I drew you but to try
How much a man, and nobly you durſt ſtand,
How well you had deſerv'd the name of vertuous;
But you, like a wild torrent, mix'd with all
Beaſtly and baſe affections came floating on,
Swelling your poiſon'd billowes—

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Will you betray me?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: To all the miſeries, a vext woman may.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Let me but out,
Give me but roome to toſſe my ſword about me,
And I will tell you, y'are a treacherous woman,
O that I had but words!

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: They will not ſerve you.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: But two-edg'd words to cut thee; a Lady traytor?
Periſh by a proud puppet? I did you too much honour,
To tender you my love, too much reſpected you,
To thinke you worthy of my worſt embraces.
Goe, take your groome, and let him dally with you,
Your greaſie groome; I ſcorne to impe your lame ſtock,
You are not faire, nor handſome, I lyed loudly.
This tongue abus'd you, when it ſpoke you beauteous.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: 'Tis very well, 'tis brave.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Put out your light,
Your aſcivious eyes, are flames enough
For fooles to find you out: a Lady plotter?
Muſt I begin, your ſacrifice of miſchiefe?
I and my friend, the firſt fruits of that blood,
You and your honourable Husband aime at?
Crooked and wretched you are both.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: To you, ſir,
Yet to the eye of Juſtice, ſtreight as Truth.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Is this a womans love? a womans mercy?
Do you profeſſe this ſeriouſly? doe you laugh at me?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Pl— light upon your ſcornes, upon your flatteries
U●on your tempting faces, all deſtructions:
A bedrid Winter hang upon your cheekes,
And blaſt, blaſt, blaſt, thoſe buds of pride that point you;
Death in your eyes to fright men from theſe dangers.
Raiſe up your trophy Cleremont.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: What a vengeance ayle you?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: What diſmall noiſe, is there, no honour in you?
Cleremont, we are betraied, betraied, ſold by a woman,
Deale bravely for thy ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: This comes of rutting:
Are we made ſtales to one another?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Yes, we are undone, loſt.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: You ſhall pay for't grey-beard:
Vp up, you ſleep your laſt elſe. Lights above, two Ser|vants and Anabell.

sp.speaker: 1 Serv.
sp.l: No not yet, ſir,
Lady, looke up: would you have wrong'd this beauty?
Wake ſo tender a Virgin, with rough tearmes?
You weare a ſword; we muſt entreat you leave it.

sp.speaker: 2 Serv.
sp.l: Fy ſir, ſo ſweet a Lady?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Was this my bed-fellow? pray give me leave to look,
I am not mad yet, I may be, by and by.
Did this ly by me?
Did I feare this? is this a cauſe to ſhake at?
Away with me for ſhame, I am a raſcall.

div.stage: Enter Champernell, Beaupre, Verdoone, Laimra, Anabel, Cleremont, and two Servants.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I am amaz'd too.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: We'll recover you.

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: You walk like Robin-good-fellow, all the houſe over
And every man afraid of you.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: 'Tis well Lady.
The honour of this deed, will be your owne,
The world ſhall know your bounty.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: What ſhall we doe with 'em?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Geld me,
For 'tis not fit I ſhould be a man againe,
I am an Aſſe, a Dog.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Take your revenges,
You know my Husbands wrongs, and your owne loſſes.

sp.speaker: Anab.
sp.l: A brave man, an admirable brave man;
Well, well, I would not be ſo tried again;
A very handſome proper gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Will you let me ly by her, but one houre more,
And then hang me?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Wee wait your malice, put your ſwords home bravely,
You have reaſon to ſeeke blood.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Not as you are Noble.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Hands off and give them liberty, onely diſarm 'em.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: We have done that already.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: You are welcome gentlemen,
I am glad my houſe, has any pleaſure for you,
I keep a couple of Ladies here, they ſay faire,
And you are young, and handſome gentlemen;
Have you any more mind to Wenches?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: To be abus'd too? Lady, you might have help'd this,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Sir now 'tis paſt, but 't may be I may ſtand,
Your friend hereafter, in a greater matter.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Never whilſt you live.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: You cannot tell—now ſir a parting hand.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Downe and Roſes:
Well, I may live to ſee you again. A dull rogue,
No revelation in thee.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Were you well frighted?
Were your fitts, from the heart, of all colds and colours?
That's all your puniſhment.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: It might have bin all yours,
Had not a blockhead undertaken it.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Your ſwords you muſt leave to theſe gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: And now, when you dare fight,
We are on even Ice againe.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: 'Tis well:
To be a Miſtris, is to be a monſter,
And ſo I leave your houſe, and you for ever.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Leave your wild luſts, and then you are a maſter.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: You may depart too.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I had rather ſtay here.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Faith we ſhall fright you worſe.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Not in that manner,
There's five hundred crownes, fright me but ſo againe.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Come Cleremont, this is the houre of foole.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Wiſer the next ſhall be or we'll to ſchoole. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: How coolely theſe hot gallants are departed?
Faith couſin 'twas unconſcionably done,
To ly ſo ſtill and ſo long.

sp.speaker: Anab.
sp.l: 'Twas your pleaſure,
If 'twere a fault I may hereafter mend.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: O, My beſt Wife.
Take now what courſe thou wilt, and lead what life.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: The more truſt you commit, the more care ſtill,
Goodneſſe and vertue, ſhall attend my will.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Let's laugh this night out now & countour gains,
We have our honours home, and they their paines.

div.head: Scena Prima.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: It holds, they will goe thither.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: To their Summer houſe?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Thither i'th' evening, and which is the moſt infliction,
Onely to inſult upon our miſeries.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Are you provided?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Throughly?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Throughly.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Baſta enough, I have your mind, I wil not faile you.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: At ſuch an houre.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Have I a memorie?
A Cauſe, and Will to doe? thou art ſo ſullen—

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: And ſhall be, till I have a faire reparation.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I have more reaſon, for I ſcaped a fortune,
Wh ch if I come ſo neare againe: I ſay nothing,
But if I ſweat not in another faſhion—
O, a delicate Wench.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: 'Tis certaine a moſt handſome one.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: And me thought the thing was angry with it ſelf too
It lay ſo long concea●d but I muſt part with you,
I have a ſcene of mirth, to drive this from my heart,
And my houre is come.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Miſſe not your time.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I dare not. Exeunt ſeverally.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I preſume, ſir, you now need no inſtruction,
But fairely know, what belongs to a Gentleman;
You beare your Uncles cauſe.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Doe not diſturbe me,
I underſtand my cauſe, and the right carriage.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Be not too bloody.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: As I find my enemy; if his ſword bite,
If it bite, ſir, you muſt pardon me.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: No doubt he is valiant,
He durſt not undertake elſe,

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Hee's moſt welcome,
As he is moſt valiant, he were no man for me elſe.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: But ſay he ſhould relent.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Hee dies relenting,
I cannot helpe it, he muſt die relenting,
If he pray, praying ipſo facto, praying,
Your honourable way, admits no prayer,
And if he ſight, he falls, there's his quiet us.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Y'are nobly punctuall, let's retire and meet 'em,
But ſtill, I ſay, have mercy.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.l: I ſay, honour. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Champernell, Lamira, Anabell, Beaupre, Ver|doone, Charlote and a ſervant.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Will not you goe ſweet-heart?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Goe? I'le fly with thee,
I ſtay behind?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: My Father will be there too,
And all our beſt friends,

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: And if we be not merry,
We have hard lucke, Lady.

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: Faith let's have a kind of play.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: What ſhall it be?

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: The ſtory of Dinant.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: With the merry conceits of Cleremont,
His fitts and Fevers.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: But I'le lie ſtill no more.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: That, as you make the Play, 'twill be rare ſport,
And how 'twill vex my gallants, when they heare it?
Have you given order for the Coach?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: My eaſie Nag, and padd.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: 'Tis making ready.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Where are your horſes?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Ready at an houre, ſir: we'll not be laſt.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Fy, what a night ſhall we have?
A roaring, merry night.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: We'll fly at all, ſir.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: I'le fly at thee too, finely, and ſo ruffle thee,
I'le try your Art, upon a Country pallet.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Brag not too much, for feare I ſhould expect it,
Then if you faile—

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Thou ſaieſt too true, we all talke,
But let's in, and prepare, and after dinner
Begin our mirthfull pilgrimage.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: He that's ſad,
A crab-fac'd Miſtris cleave to him for this yeare. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Since it cannot be the Judge—

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: 'Tis a great deale better.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: You are ſure, he is his kinſman? a gentleman?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: As arrant a gentleman, and a brave fellow,
And ſo neare to his blood—

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: It ſhall ſuffice,
I'le ſet him further off, I'le give a remove
Shall quit his kindred, I'le lopp him.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Will ye kill him?

sp.speaker: La-w.
sp.l: And there were no more coſins in the world I kil him,
I do mean, ſir, to kill all my Lords kindred.
For every Cauſe a couſin.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: How if he have no more couſins.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: The next a kin then, to his Lordſhips favour,
The man he ſmiles upon.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Why this is vengeance, horrid, and dire.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: I love a dire revenge:
Give me the man, that will all others kill,
And laſt himſelfe,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: You ſtole that reſolution.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: I had it in a Play, but that's all one,
I woo'd ſee it done.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Come, you muſt be more mercifull.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: To no Lords coſins in the world, I hate 'em;
A Lords coſin to me is a kind of Cocatrice,
If I ſee him firſt, he dies.
A ſtrange Antipathy,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: What think you of their Neeces?

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: If I like 'em,
They may live, and multiply; 'tis a cold morning.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: 'Tis ſharpe indeed; you have broke your faſt.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: No verily.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Your valour would have ask'd a good foundation.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Hang him, I'le kill him faſting.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Here they come,
Beare your ſelfe in your language, ſmooth and gently,
When your ſwords argue.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: 'Pray ſir ſpare your precepts.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I have brought you ſir—

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: 'Tis very well, no words,
You are welcome, ſir.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: I thanke you, ſir, few words.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: I'le kill you for your Uncles ſake.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: I love you,
I'le cut your throat, for your owne ſake.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: I eſteeme of you.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Let's render 'em honeſt, and faire, gentlemen,
Search my friend, I'le ſearch yours.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: That's quickly done.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: You come with no ſpells, nor witchcrafts?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: I come fairely, to kill him honeſtly.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Hang Spells, and Witchcrafts,
I come to kill my Lords Nephew like a gentleman,
And ſo I kiſſe his hand.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: This doublet is too ſtiffe.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Off woo't, I hate it,
And all ſuch fortifications, feele my skin,
If that be ſtiffe, flea that off too.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: 'Tis no ſoft one.

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Off, woo't, I ſay:
I'le fight with him, like a flead Catt.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: You are well, you are well. Put off.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: You muſt uncaſe too.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Yes, ſir.
But tell me this, why ſhould I mix mine honour
With a fellow, that has ne'r a lace in's ſhirt?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: That's a maine point, my friend has two.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: That's true, ſir.

sp.speaker: La-w.
sp.l: Baſe and degenerate couſin, doeſt not thou know
An old, and tatter'd colours, to the enemy,
Is of more honour, and ſhewes more ominous?
This ſhirt, five times, victorious I have fought under,
And cut through ſquadrons, of your curious Cut-workes,
As I will doe through thine, ſhake, and be ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: This is unanſwerable.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: But may I fight, with a foule ſhirt?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Moſt certaine, ſo it be a fighting ſhirt,
Let it be ne'r ſo foule, or lowſie, Caeſar wore ſuch a one.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Saint Denis then: I accept your ſhirt.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Not ſo forward, firſt you muſt talke,
'Tis a maine point, of the French method,
Talke civilly, and make your cauſe Authentique.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: No weapon muſt be neare you, nor no anger.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: When you have done, then ſtir your reſolutions,
Take to your Weapons bravely.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: 'Tis too cold;
This for a Summer fight.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Not for a world, you ſhould tranſgreſſe the rules.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: 'Tis peeviſh weather,
I had rather fight without.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: An 'twere in a river.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Where both ſtood up to th' chins.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Then let's talke quickly,
Pl— o' this circumſtance.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Are the Horſes come yet?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Yes certaine: give your ſwords to us, now civilly.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: We'll ſtand a while off; take the things, & leave 'em,
You know when, and let the children play:
This is a dainty time of yeare for puppies,
Would the old Lord were here.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: He would dy with laughter.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I am ſorry I have no time, to ſee this game out,
Away, away.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Here's like to be a hot fight,
Call when y'are fit. Ex. Cler. and Gent.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Why look you ſir, you ſeem to be a gentleman,
And you come in honour of your Uncle, boh, boh, 'tis very cold;
Your Uncle has offer'd me ſome few affronts,
Paſt fleſh and blood to beare: boh, boh, wondrous cold.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: My Lord, mine Uncle, is an honourable man,
And what he offers, boh, boh, cold indeed,
Having made choice of me, an unworthy kinſman,
Yet, take me with you: boh, boh, peſtlence cold,
Not altogether.

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Boh, boh, I ſay altogether.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: You ſay you know not what then: boh, boh, ſir.

sp.speaker: La-w.
sp.l: Sir me with your ſword in your hand;
You have a ſcurvy Uncle, you have a moſt ſcurvy cauſe,
And you are — boh, boh.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Boh, boh, what?

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: A ſhitten ſcurvy Couſin.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.l: Our Swords? our ſwords?
Thou art a dog, and like a dog: our ſwords?

sp.speaker: La-w.
sp.l: Our weapons gentlemen: ha? wher's your ſecond?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Where's yours?

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: So ho? our weapons?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Wa, ha, ho, our weapons?
Our Doublets and our weapons, I am dead.

sp.speaker: La-w.
sp.l: Firſts? ſecond? third? a pl—be woo' you gentlemen

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Are theſe the rules of honour? I am ſtarv'd.

sp.speaker: La-w.
sp.l: They are gone, and we are here; what ſhall we do?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: O for a couple of faggots.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Hang a couple of faggots;
Dar'ſt thou take a killing cold with me?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: I have it already.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Rogues, theeves, boh boh, run away with our Doublets?
To fight at Buffets now, 'twere ſuch a May-game.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: There were no honour in't, p— on't, 'tis ſcurvy.

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Or to revenge my wrongs at fifty-cuffes.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: My Lord, mine Uncles cauſe, depend on Boxes?

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Let's goe in queſt, if ever we recover 'em.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: I, come, our colds together, and our doublets.

sp.speaker: La-w.
sp.l: Give me thy hand; thou art a valiant gentleman.
I ſay, if ever we recover 'em—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Let's get into a houſe and warme our hearts.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: There's ne'r a houſe within this mile, beat me,
Kick me, and beat me as I goe, and I'le beat thee too,
To keepe us warme; if ever we recover 'em—
Kick hard, I am frozen: ſo, ſo, now I feele it.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: I am dull yet.

sp.speaker: La-w.
sp.l: I'le warme thee I'le warme thee.—Gentlemen,
Rogues, theeves, theeves: run, now I'le follow thee. Exeūt.

div.stage: Enter Vertaigne, Champernell Beaupre, Verdoone, Lamira, Annabell. Charlote, Nurſe.

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Uſe legs, and have legs.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: You that have legs ſay ſo,
I put my one to too much ſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Verdo.
sp.l: Your herſe, ſir,
Will meet you within halfe a mile,

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I like
The walke ſo well, I ſhould not miſſe my Coach,
Though it were further. Annabell thou art ſad:
What ayles my Niece?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Shee's ſtill deviſing, ſiſter,
How quietly her late bed-fellow lay by her.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: Old as I am, he would have ſtartled me,
Nor can you blame her.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Had I ta'ne her place.
I know not, but I feare, I ſhould ha' ſhreek'd,
Though he had never offer'd—

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Out upon thee,
Thou wouldſt have taught him.

sp.speaker: Charlote.
sp.l: I thinke, with your pardon,
That you wiſh now you had.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: I am glad. I yeild you Cornet. Muſicke within.
Such ample ſcope of mirth.

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Nay, be not angrie,
There's no ill meant: ha? Muſique, and choice muſique?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: 'Tis near us in the Grove what courteous bounty
Beſtowes it on us? my dancing daies are done;
Yet I would thanke the giver, did I know him.

sp.speaker: Verdo.
sp.l: 'Tis queſtionleſſe, ſome one of your own Village,
That hearing of your purpos'd journey thither,
Prepares it for your entertainment, and
The honour of my Lady.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I thinke rather,
Some of your Lordſhips Clyents.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: What ſay you Couſin?
If they ſhould prove your Suitors?

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: That's moſt likely.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: I ſay, if you are noble, be't who will;
Goe preſently and thanke 'em: I can jump yet,
Or tread a meaſure.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Like a Millers Mare.

sp.speaker: Nurſ.
sp.l: I warrant you well enough to ſerve the Country,
I'le make one, and lead the way. Exit.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Doe you note,
How zealous the old Crone is?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: And you titter
As eagerly as ſhe: come ſweet, we'll follow,
No ill can be intended. Muſ. ends.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: I ne'r fear'd yet. Exeunt.
THis way, this way, come and heare,
You that hold, theſe pleaſures deare,
Fill your eares, with our ſweet ſound,
Whilſt we melt the frozen ground:
This way come, make haſt ô faire,
Let your cleare eyes gild the ayer;
Come and bleſſe us with your ſight,
This way, this way ſeeke delight.

div.stage: Enter a company of Gentlemen, like Ruffians.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: They are ours but draw them on a little further
From the foot-path into the neighbouring thicket,
And we may do't, as ſafe, as in a Caſtle.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: They follow ſtill; the Preſident, Vertaigne
Comes on a-pace, and Champernell limps after;
The women, as if they had wings, and walk't
Upon the ayre, fly to us.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: They are welcome,
We'll make 'em ſport; make a ſtand here, all know
How we are to proceed.

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: We are inſtructed. Still Muſick within.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: One ſtraine or two more. Gent. off.
sp.stage: Enter Vertaigne, Champernell, Beaupre Verdoone, Lamira, Anabell, Nurſe, Charlote.
sp.l: Excellent, they are come,

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: We cannot miſſe, in ſuch a buſineſſe, yet
Mine eare ne'r fail'd me. Muſick for the Dance.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Would we were at it once,
I doe not walke, but dance.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: You ſhall have dancing.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Begin, and when I give the word—

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: No more.
Weare inſtructed. Dance.

sp.speaker: Beaupre.
sp.l: But win us fairely— Now.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: O ſir, We do not come to try your valour,
But to poſſeſs you, yet we uſe you kindly
In that, like Engliſh theeves, wee kill you not,
But are contented with the ſpoile.

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Oh heaven!
How hath mine age deſerv'd this?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Hell confound it,
This comes of walking; had I kept my legs,
My legs in my good houſe, my Armour on,
My Staffe in my reſt, and this good ſword too, friend,
How I would breake and ſcatter theſe.

sp.speaker: All Gent.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Doe you ſcorne me rogues?

sp.speaker: Nurſ.
sp.l: Nay, Gentlemen, kind gentlemen,
Or honeſt keepers of theſe woods, but heare me,
Be not ſo rough; if you are taken with
My beauty, as it hath bin worth the ſeeking,
Some one or two of you, try me in private,
You ſhall not find me ſqueamiſh.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Doe not kill me,
And doe your worſt, I'le ſuffer.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Peace vile creatures.

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: Do you know me, or my place that you preſume not
To touch my perſon?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: If you are well, reſt ſo,
Provoke not angry waſpes.

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: You are Waſpes indeed,
Never created to yeild VVax, or honey,
But for your Countries torment, yet are, if men,
As you ſeeme ſuch in ſhape, if true borne French-men,
How ever want compells you to theſe courſes,
Reſt ſatisfied with what you can take from us,
(Theſe Ladies honours, and our liberties ſafe)
VVe freely give it.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: You give but our owne.

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Looke on theſe grey haires, as you would be old,
Their teares, as you would have yours to find mercy,
VVhen Juſtice ſhall o'retake you.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Looke on me,,
Looke on me raſcalls, and learne of me too,
That have bin in ſome part of your profeſſion,
Before that moſt of you ere ſuck'd I know it,
I have rode hard, and late too.

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Take heed, ſir.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Then uſe me, like a brother of the trade,
For I have been at Sea, as you on land are,
Reſtore my Matrimony undefil'd,
VVrong not my Neece. and for our gold or ſilver,
If I purſue you, hang me.

sp.speaker: Nurſ.
sp.l: 'Tis well offer'd,
And as I ſaid, ſweet gentlemen, with ſowre faces,
If you are high, and want ſome ſport, or ſo,
(As living without action here, you may doe)
Forbeare their tender griſſells, they are meate
VVill waſh away, there is no ſubſtance in it,
VVe that are expert in the game, and tough to,
VVill hold you play.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: This hen longs to be troden.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Lackey my horſe.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: This way, I heard the cries
Of diſtreſs'd women.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Stand upon your guard.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: VVho's here? my witty, ſcornfull Lady-plot?
In the hands of ruffians,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: And my fine cold virgin,
That was inſenſible of man, and woman?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Juſtice too,
Without a ſword to guard it ſelf?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: And valour with its hands bound?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: And the great Souldier dull?
Why this is ſtrange;

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Dinant as thou art noble —

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: As thou art valiant Cleremont. —

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: As ever I appear'd lovely —

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: As you ever hope,
For what I would give gladly —

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Pretty conjurations,

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: All injuries, a little laied behind you

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Shew your ſelves men, and help us

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Though your many
And groſſe abuſes of me, ſhould more move me
To triumph in your miſeries then releive you, —
Yet that hereafter, you may know that I
The ſcorne and deſpis'd Dinant, knows what does.
Belong to honour, thus —

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I will ſay little, Fight.
Speake thou for me,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: 'Tis bravely fought,

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Brave tempers,
To doe thus for their enemies.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: They are loſt yet,

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: You that would reſcue others, ſhall now feele
What they were borne to,

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.p: Hurry them away. Exit. Manent Vertaigne, and Champernell.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: That I could follow them,

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: I only can lament my fortune, and deſire of heaven
A little life for my revenge.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: The provoſt,
Shall fire the woods, but I will find e'm out,
No cave, no rocke, nor hell ſhall keepe them from
My ſearching vengeance.

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: O cold! o fearfull cold! plague of all ſeconds,

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: O for a pint of burnt wine, or a ſip
Of aqua fortis.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: The rogues have met with theſe two
Upon my life and robd 'em

sp.speaker: La. Wr.
sp.l: As you are honourable Gentlemen,
Impart unto a couple of cold combatants,

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: My Lord, mine uncle as I live,

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Pox take him.
How that word, has warm,d my mouth?

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Why how now Couſen?
Why, why? and where man, bave you bin? at a Poulters
That you are caſs'd thus like a rabbet? I could laugh now,
And I ſhall laugh, for all I have loſt my Children,
Laugh monſtruouſly

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: What are they?

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Give me leave Sir,
Laugh more and more, never leave laughing,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Why Sir?

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Why 'tis ſuch a thing I ſmell it Sir, I ſmell it,
Such a ridiculous thing, —

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Do you laugh at me my Lord?
I am very cold, but that ſhould not be laught at,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: What art thou?

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: What art thou?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: If he had his doublet. —
And his ſword by his ſide, as a Gentleman ought to have

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Peace Mounſier Sampſon.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Come hither little Gentleman,

sp.speaker: La wr.
sp.l: Baſe is the ſlave commanded: come to me

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: This is the little advocate

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: What advocate?

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: The little advocate that ſent me a challenge,
I told you that my Nephew under tooke it,
And what t'was like to prove: now you ſee the iſſue.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Is this the little Lawyer?

sp.speaker: La. wr.
sp.l: You have a ſword Sir,
And I have none, you have a doublet too,
That keepes you warme, and makes you merry,

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: If your Lordſhip knew.
The nature, and the nobleneſſe of the Gentleman,
Though he ſhew ſleight here, & at what guſts of danger
His manhood has arrived,

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Bee't ●hen.
Mens faces are fooliſh,
And often head long, over run their fortunes,

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: That little Lawyer, would ſo pricke his eares up,
And bite your honour by the noſe.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Say you ſo Sir?

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.p: So niggle about your grave ſhins Lord Vertaigne too

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: No more ſweet Gentleman, no more of that Sir,

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: I will have more, I muſt have more.

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Out with it.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Nay he is as brave a fellow.—

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Have I caught you? Strike him downe.

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Doe not kill him, doe not kill him.
No no, no, I will not

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Doe you peepe againe, downe downe proud heart

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: O valour,
Looke up brave friend, I have no meanes to reſcue thee,
My Kingdome for a ſword,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: I'll ſword you preſently,
I'll claw your skin-coate too.

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Away good Samſon,
You goe to graſſe els inſtantly,

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: But doe not murder my brave friend

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: Not one word,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: If you doe ſirra, —

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Muſt I goe off diſhonour'd?
Adverſity tries valour, ſo I leave thee. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Are you a Lawyer Sir?

sp.speaker: La-Wr.
sp.l: I was, I was Sir,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Nay never looke, your Lawyers pate is broken
And your litigious blood, about your eares ſirra,
Why doe you fight and ſnarle?

sp.speaker: La. Wr.
sp.l: I was poſſeſt.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Ile dispoſeſſe you.

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: Ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: La-Wr.
sp.l: Et tu Brute.

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: Beate him no more.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Alas Sir I muſt beate him,
Beate him into his buſineſſe agen, he will be loſt els.

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: Then take your way,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Ly ſtill, and doe not ſtruggle,

sp.speaker: La-Wr.
sp.l: I am patient,
I never ſaw my blood before, it jades me,
I have no more heart now then a gooſe.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Why ſirra, why do you leave your trade, your trade of living,
And ſend your challenges like thunderbolts,
To men of honour'd place?

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: I underſtand Sir,
I never underſtood, before your beating,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Does this worke on you?

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Doe you thanke me for't?

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: As well as a beaten man can,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: And doe you promiſe me,
To fall cloſe to your trade againe? leave brawling

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: If you will give me leave and life,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: And aske this noble man forgiveneſſe?

sp.speaker: La-Wr.
sp.l: Hartily.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Riſe then, and get you gone, and let me heare of you
As of an Advocate new vampt; no more words,
Get you off quickly, and make no murmurs
I ſhall purſue you elſe,

sp.speaker: La-Wr.
sp.l: I have done ſweet Gentlemen. Exit.

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: But we forget our ſelves, our Friends and Children

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Wee'l raiſe the coūtry firſt, then take our fortunes.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Shall I entereate for what I may command?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Thinke on my birth,

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Here I am only Noble.
A King, and thou in my dominions foole,
A ſubject and a ſlave.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Be nor a Tyrant;
A raviſher of honour, gentle Sir,
And I will thinke ye ſuch, and on my knees,
As to my Soveraigne, pay a Subjects duty,
With prayers and teares,

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: I like this humble carriage.
I will walke by, but kneele you ſtill and weepe too,
It ſhewes well, while I meditate on the prey,
Before I ſeize it.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Is there no mercie, heaven?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Not kiſſe you?
I will kiſſe and kiſſe againe,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Savage vill ame!
My Innocence be my ſtrength, I doe defie thee,
Thus ſcorne and ſpit at thee; will you come on Sir,
You are hot, there is a cooler,

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: A virago?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: No, lothſome Goate, more, more I am that Goddeſſe,
That here with whippes of ſteele in hell hereafter
Scourge rape and theft,

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: I'll try your deity,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: My chaſtity, and this knife held by a Virgin,
Againſt thy luſt thy ſword and thee a Beaſt.
Call on for the encounter.

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: Now what thinke you? Throwes her and takes. her Knife.
Are you a Goddeſſe?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: In me their power ſuffers,
That ſhould protect the Innocent,

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: I am all fire,
And thou ſhall quench it, and ſerve my pleaſures,
Come partner in the ſpoile and the reward,
Let us enjoy our purchaſe

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: O Dinant!
O Heaven! o Husband!

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: O my Cleremont!

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Two are our ſlaves they call on, bring 'em forth
As they are chaind together let them ſee
And ſuffer in the object.

div.stage: Enter Dinant and Cleremont bound. By the reſt of the Gent.

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: While we ſit
And without pitty heare 'em

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: By my life,
I ſuffer more for thee then for my ſelf,

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Be a man Cleremont, and looke upon 'em,
As ſuch that not alone abus'd our ſervice,
Fed us with hopes moſt bitter indigeſtion,
But when love faild, to draw on further miſcheif,
The baites they laied for us; were our owne honours,
Which thus hath made us ſlaves too, worſe then ſlaves

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: He dies

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Pray hold, give him a little reſpite,

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I ſee you now beyond expreſſion wretched,
The wit you bragd of, foold, that boaſted honour,
As you beleev'd compaſs'd with walls of braſſe,
To guard it ſure, Subject to be o're throwne
With the leaſt blaſt of luſt.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: A moſt ſad truth.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: That confidence which was not to be ſhaken
In a perpetuall fever, and thoſe favours,
Which with ſo ſtrong, and Ceremonious duty
Your lover and a Gentleman long ſought for,
Sought, ſued, and kneeld in vaine for, muſt you yeild up
To a licentious villaine, that will hardly,
Allow you thanks for't

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Something I muſt ſay too,
And to you pretty one, though crying one;
To be hangd now, when theſe worſhipful benchers pleaſe
Though I know not their faces that condemne me,
A little ſtartles me, but a man is nothing,
A Maydenhead is the thing, the thing all aime at;
Doe not you wiſh now, and wiſh from your heart too,
When ſcarce ſweet with my feares, I long lay by you
Thoſe feares you and your good Aunt put upon me,
To make you ſport you had giuen a little hint,
A touch or ſo, to tell me I was mortall,
And by a mortall woman?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Pray you no more

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: If I had loos'd that virgin Zone, obſerve me,
I would have hired the beſt of all our Poets
To have ſung ſo much, and ſo well in the honour
Of that nights joye, that Ovids afternoone,
Nor his Corvina ſhould againe be mentioned,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: I doe repent, and wiſh I had,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: That's comfort,
But now. —

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Another that will have it offer'd,
Compell it to be offer'd, ſhall enjoye it.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: A rogue, a ruffian.

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: As you love your throat, —

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Away with them.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: O Cleremont!

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: O Dinant!

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I can but add your ſorrowes to my ſorrowes,
Your feares to my feares,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: To your wiſhes mine.
This ſlave may prove unable to performe,
Till I performe the taske thar I was borne for,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Amen, amen.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Drag the ſlaves hence, for you
A while i'll locke you up here ſtudy all wayes
You can to pleaſe me, or the deed being done,
You are but dead.

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: This ſtrong vault ſhall conteine you
There thinke how many for your maydenhead
Have pin'd away, and be prepared to looſe it
With penitence.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: No humane help can ſave you.

sp.speaker: Ladyes.
sp.l: Helpe, helpe?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: You cry in vaine, rockes cannot heare you.

div.head: Scena Prima.
div.stage: A Horrid noiſe of Muſique within, Enter one and opens the Chamber doore, in which La|mira and Anabell were ſhut, they in all feare.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: O Couſen how I ſhake, all this long night,
What frights and noiſes we have heard ſtill they encreaſe
The villaines put on ſhapes to torture us,
And to their Divells forme ſuch preparations
As if they were a hatching new diſhonours,
And fatall ruine, paſt dull mans invention
Goe not too far and pray good Couſen Anabell
Harke a new noiſe. A ſtrange Muſick. Sackbut & Troup muſick.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: They are exquiſite in miſcheif.
I will goe on this roome gives no protection,
More then the next what's that? how ſad and hollow,
The ſound comes to us. Theeves peeping. Lowder.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Groning? or ſinging is it?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: The wind I think, murmuring amongſt old rooms

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Now it growes lowder ſure ſome ſad pteſage
Of our fowle loſſe — peepe —, looke now they peepe,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Pox peepe 'em.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: O give them gentle language,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Give 'em rats-bane. Peepe above.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Now they are above

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: I would they were i th Center,

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Thou art ſo fooliſh deſperate,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Since we muſt looſe.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Call 'em brave fellowes, Gentlemen,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Call 'em rogues,
Rogues as they are, rude rogues, uncivill villaines

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Look an thou woot, beware doſt thou feele the danger?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Till the danger feele me, this will I talke ſtill,
And worſe when that comes too; they cannot eate me
This is a puniſhment, upon our owne prides,
Moſt juſtly laied; we muſt abuſe brave Gentlemen,
Make 'em tame fooles & hobby-horſes, laugh & jeere at
Such men too, and ſo handſome and ſo Noble,
That howſoere we ſeem'd to carry it
Woo'd 'twer to doe againe,

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I doe confeſſe couſen,
It was too harſh, too fooliſh

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Doe you feele it?
Doe you find it now? take heed ot'h puniſhment,
We might have had two gallant Gentlemen,
Proper young, o how it tortures me
Two Divells now, two raſcalls two and twenty

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: O thinke not ſo

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Nay an we ſcape ſo modeſtly —

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: May we be worthy any eyes, or knowledge,
When we are uſed thus?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Why not? why doe you cry!
Are we not women ſtill? what were we made for?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: But thus, thus baſely —

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: 'Tis againſt our wills,
And if there come a thouſand ſo, —

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Out on thee,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: You are a foole, what we cannot reſiſt,
Why ſhould we greive and bluſh for? there be women,
And they that beare the name of excellent women
Would give their whole eſtates, to meete this fortune

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Harke, a new noiſe. New found within.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Let 'em goe on, I feare not,
If wrangling fighting and ſcratching cannot preſerve me
Why ſo be it Couſen; if I be ordain'd
To breed a race of rogues. —

div.stage: Enter foure over the ſtage with Beaupre and Ver|doone bound and halters about ●heir necks.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: They come

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Be firme,
They are wellcom.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: What mask of death is this? O my deare Brother

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: My cooſe to; why now y'are glorious villaines

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: O ſhall we looſe our honours?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Let 'em goe,
When death prepares the way, they are but Pageant●
Why muſt theſe dye?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Lament your owne misfortunes
We periſh happily before your ruines,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Has mischeif ne'r a tongue?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Yes fooliſh woman,
Our Captaines will is death.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: You dare not doe it
Tell thy baſe boiſterous Captaine what I ſay,
Thy lawleſſe Captaine that he dares not;
Doe you laugh you rogue? you pamperd rogue?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Good Sir,
Good Couſen gently, as y'are a Gentleman,—

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: A gentleman? a ſlave a dog the devills harbinger

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Sir as you had a mother,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: He a Mother?
Shame not the name of mother, a ſhe Beare
A bloody old woolf bitch, a woman Mother?
Lookes that rude lumpe, as if he had a mother?
Intreat him? hang him, do thy worſt thou darſt not,
Thou dar'ſt not wrong their lives, thy Captain dares not
They are perſons of more price

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: What ere we ſuffer
Let not your angers wrong you,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: You cannot ſuffer.
The men that doe this deed muſt live i'th moone
Free from the gripe of Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Is it not better?

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: Is it not better? let 'em goe on like raſcalls
And put falſe faces on; they dare not doe it;
Flatter ſuch ſcabbs of nature,

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Woman, woman
The next worke is with you,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Unbind thoſe Gentlemen,
And put their fatall fortunes, on our neckes.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: As you have mercy doe;

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: As you are monſters.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Fright us no more with ſhipwrack of our honours
Nor if there be a guilt by us committed
Let it endanger thoſe,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: I ſay they dare not,
There be a thouſand gallouſes, yee rogues,
Tortures, ye bloody rogues wheeles,

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: A way.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Stay.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Stay,
Stay and i'll flatter too: good ſweet fac'd Gentlemen
You excellent in honeſty; o kinſmen!
O Noble kinſmen!

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Away with 'em. Exit Verta. Beaup. and Gent.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Stay yet
The Devill and his lovely dam walke with you,
Come fortify your ſelf, if they doe dy,
Which all their ruggedneſſe, cannot rack into me
They cannot find an houre more Innocent,
Nor more friends to revenge 'em.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Now ſtand conſtant,
For now our tryalls come,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: This beauties mine
Your minute moves not yet,

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: She ſinkes if Chriſtian,
If any ſparke of noble heate.—

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Riſe Lady
And feareleſſe riſe, there's no diſhonour meant you,
Doe you know my tongue?

sp.speaker: Ana,
sp.l: I have heard it,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Marke it better
I am one that loves you, fairely, nobly loves you
Looke on my face?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: O Sir?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: No more words, ſoftly
Hearke, but hearke wiſely how, underſtand well,
Suſpect not, feare not

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: You have brought me comfort

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: If you thinke me worthy of your Husband,
I am no rogue, nor Begger if you dare doe thus —

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: You are Mounſier Cleremont,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I am the ſame
If you dare venture, ſpeake, if not I leave you,
And leave you to the mercy of theſe villaines
That will not wooe ye much,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Save my reputation,
And free me from theſe ſlaves.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: By this kiſſe i'll doe it
And from the leaſt diſhonour they dare aime at you
I have a prieſt too, ſhall be ready.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: You are forward,

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Is this my conſtant Couſen? how ſhe whiſpers,
Kiſſes and huggs the theif.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: You ll offer nothing

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Till all be tyed
Not as I am a Gentleman

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Can you releive my Aunt too?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Not yet Miſtris.
But feare nothing all ſhall be well away quickly
It muſt be done i'th moment or

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: I am with yee

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I'll know now who ſleepes by me, keepe your ſtan|ding

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Well, go thy wayes, & thine own ſhame dwell with thee?
Is this the conſtancy ſhe ſhewed the bravery
The deare love and the life, ſhe owed her kinsmen?
O brave tongue valiant glorious woman?
Is this the noble anger you arriv'd at?
Are theſe the theeves you ſcornd the rogues you rayld at?
The ſcabs and ſcums of nature? o faire modeſty,
Excellent vertue, whither art thou fled?
What hand of heaven is over us, when ſtrong virgins
Yeild to their feares, and to their feares their fortunes?
Never beleef come neare me more, farewell wench,
A long farewell from all that ever knew thee
My turne is next,
I am reſolved it comes
But in a nobler ſhape, ha?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Bleſſe yee Lady

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Indeed Sir. I had need of many bleſſings,
For all the houres I have had ſince I came here,
Have bin ſo many curſes. How got you liberty?
For I preſume you come to comfort me

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: To comfort you, and love you, 'tis moſt true,
My bondage was as yours, as full of bitterneſſe
And every hower my death.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Heaven was your comfort.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Till the laſt evening, ſitting full of ſadneſſe
Wailing, ſweet Miſtris, your unhappy fortunes
Mine owne I had the leaſt care of round about me,
The Captaine, and the company ſtood gaping,
When I began the ſtory of my love,
To you faire Saint, and with ſo full a ſorrow,
Followed each point, that even from thoſe rude eyes,
That never knew what pitty meant or mercy
Ther ſtole downe ſoft relentings, take heed Miſtris,
And let not ſuch unholy hearts out doe you,
The ſoft plum'd god will ſee againe thus taken,
As men transform'd with the ſtrange tale I told
They ſtood amaz'd then bid me riſe and live,
Take liberty and meanes to ſee your perſon,
And wiſht me proſperous in your love, wiſh you ſo,
Be wiſe and loving Lady, ſhew but you ſo

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: O Sir, are theſe fit houres, to talke of love in?
Shall we make fooles of our afflictions?
Can any thing ſound ſweetly in mine eares,
Where all the noiſe of bloody horrour?
My Brother, and my Couſen, they are dead Sir,
Dead, baſely dead, is this an age to foole in?
And I my ſelf, I know not what I ſhall be
Yet I muſt thanke you and if happily
You had asked me yeſterday, when theſe were living,
And my feares leſſe, I might have hearkned to you,

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Peace to your grief, I bind you to your word.

div.stage: Enter Cleremont Anabell, Beaupre, Verdoone, Charlote Nurſe, the two Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: How? doe you conjure?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Not to raiſe dreadfull apparitions, Madam,
But ſuch as you would gladly ſee.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: My Brother, and nephew living?

sp.speaker: Beap.
sp.l: And both owe their lives,
To the favour of theſe Gentlemen,

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: Who deſerve
Our ſervice, and for us, your gracious thankes.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Which I give freely, and become a ſuitour,
To be hereafter more familiar. Kiſſe.
With ſuch great worth and vertue,

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Ever thinke us,
Your ſervants Madam.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Why if thou wilt needs know
How we are freed, I will diſcover it,
And with laconick brevity, theſe Gentlemen
This night incountring with thoſe out lawes that
Yeſterday made us priſoners, and as we were
Attempted by 'em they with greater courage,
(I am ſure with better fortune not alone,
Guarded themſelves, but forc'd the bloody thieves,
Being got betweene them, and this helliſh Cave,
For ſafety of their lives, to fly up higher
Into the woods, all left to their poſſeſſion
This ſave your Brother, and your nephew from
The gibbet, this redeem'd me from my Chaines,
And gave my friend his liberty this preſerv'd
Your honour ready to be loſt.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: But that
I know this for a ly, and that the thieves
And gentlemen, are the ſame men, by my practiſe,
Suborn'd to this he does deliver it
With ſuch a conſtant brow, that I am doubtfull,
I ſhould believe him too.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: If we did well,
We are rewarded.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Thankes but takes away
From what was freely purpos'd.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Now by this hand,
You have ſo cunningly diſcharg'd your parts,
That while we live, reſt confident you ſhall
Command Dinant and Cleremont, nor Beaupr●,
Nor Verdoone ſents it: for the Ladyes, they
Were eaſie to be gul'd.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: 'Twas but a jeſt,
And yet the jeſt, may chance to breake our neckes
Should it be knowne.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Feare nothing.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Say, what ſucceſſe?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: As thou wouldſt wiſh, 'tis done Lad,
The grove will witneſſe with me, that this night,
I lay not like a blocke: but how ſpeed you?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I yet am in ſuſpence, deviſe ſome meanes
To get theſe off, and ſpeedily.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I have it,
Come, we are dull, I thinke that the good fellowes,
Our predeceſſors in this place, were not
So fooliſh, and improvident husbands, but
'Twill yeild us meat, and wine.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Let's ranſack it,
'Tis ours now, by the Law.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: How ſay you ſweet one,
Have you an appetite?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: To walke againe
I'th Woods, if you thinke fit, rather then eate.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: A little reſpite prithee; nay bluſh not,
You aske but whats your owne, and warrantable
What thinke you of the motion?

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: Lead the way. Ex. Manent, Din. and Lamira.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: We follow willingly.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: When you ſhall thinke fit,
We will expect you.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Now be miſtris of
Your promiſe Lady.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: 'Twas to give you hearing.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: But that word hearing, did include a grant,
And you muſt make it good.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Muſt?

sp.speaker: D●n.
sp.l: Muſt, and ſhall,
I will be fool'd no more, you had your tricks;
Made properties, of me, and of my friend;
Preſum'd upon your power, and whip'd me with
The rod of mine owne dotage: doe not flatter
Your ſelfe, with hope, that any humane helpe
Can free you, and for ayde by miracle;
A baſe unthankfull woman is unworthy.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: You will not force me?
Rather then enjury you
With your conſent becauſe I will torment you;
I'le make you feele the effects of abus'd love,
And glory in your torture.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Brother, Nephew,
Helpe, helpe, for heavens ſake.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Teare your throat, cry lowder,
Though every leafe, theſe trees beare, were an Eccho,
And ſummond in your beſt friends to redeeme you,
It ſhould be fruitleſſe: 'tis not that I love you,
Or value thoſe delights you prize ſo high,
That I'le enjoy you, a French crowne will buy
More ſport, and a companion, to whom,
You in your beſt trim. are an Ethiope.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Forbeare me then.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Not ſo, I'll do't in ſpite,
And breake that ſtubborne diſobedient will,
That hath ſo long held out, that boaſted honour,
I will make equall with a common VVhores;
The ſpring of Chaſtity, that fed your pride,
And grew into a River of vaine glory,
I will defile with mudd, the mudd of luſt,
And make it lothſome even to goats.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: O heaven!
No pitty ſir?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: You taught me to be cruell,
And dare you thinke of mercy? I'le tell thee foole,
Thoſe that ſurpriz'd thee, were my inſtruments,
I can plot too, good Madam, you ſhall find it:
And in the ſtead of licking of my fingers,
Kneeling, and whining like a boy new breech'd,
To get a toy forſooth, not worth an apple,
Thus make my way, and with Authority,
Command what I would have.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I am loſt for ever:
Good ſir, I doe confeſſe my fault, my groſſe fault,
And yeild my ſelfe up, miſerable guilty;
Thus kneeling, I confeſſe, you cannot ſtudy
Sufficient puniſhments, to load me with;
I am in your power, and I confeſſe againe,
You cannot be too cruell: if there be,
Beſides the loſſe of my long guarded honour,
Any thing elſe to make the ballance even:
Pray put it in, all hopes, all helpes have left me;
I am girt round with ſorrow, hell's about me,
And raviſhment, the leaſt that I can looke for,
Doe what you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Indeed I will doe nothing,
Nor touch, nor hur● you Lady, nor had ever
Such a lewd purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Can there be ſuch goodneſſe,
And in a man ſo injur'd?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Be confirmed in't.
I ſeale it thus: I muſt confeſſe you vex'd me,
In fooling me ſo often, and thoſe feares,
You threw upon me, call'd for a requitall,
Which now I have return'd, all unchaſt love
Dinant thus throwes away; live to man-kind,
As you have done to me, and I will honour
Your vertue, and no more thinke of your beauty.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: All I poſſeſſe, comes ſhort of ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: No complements: the terrours of this night
Imagine, but a fearfull dreame, and ſo
With eaſe forget it: for Dinant, that labour'd
To blaſt your honour, is a Champion for it,
And will protect and guard it.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: 'Tis as ſafe then,
As if a compleat Army undertooke it. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Do not perſwade me gentle Monſier Sampſon,
I am a mortall man againe, a Lawyer,
My mortall part, I have put off.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Sweet Monſier,
Let but our honours teach us.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Monſier Sampſon
My honourable friend, my valiant friend,
Be but ſo beaten-forward my brave Clyents,
I am yours, and you are mine againe, be but ſo thraſht,
Receive that Caſtigation with a cudgell.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Which calls upon us for a Reparation.

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: I have, it coſt me halfe a crowne, I beare it
All over me, I beare it Monſier Sampſon;
The oyles, and the old woman, that repaires to me,
To noint my beaten body.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: It concernes you,
You have bin ſwing'd.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Let it concerne thee too;
Goe and be beaten, ſpeake ſcurvy words, as I did,
Speake to that Lion Lord, waken his anger,
And have a hundred Baſtinado's, doe;
Three broken pates, thy teeth knockt out, doe Sampſon,
Thy valiant armes and leggs beaten to Poulteſſes,
Doe ſilly Sampſon, doe.

sp.speaker: 1 Cly.
sp.l: You wrong the gentleman,
To put him out of his right minde thus:
You wrong us, and our Cauſes.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Downe with him gentlemen,
Turne him, and beat him, if he breake our peace,
Then when thou haſt bin Lam'd, thy ſmall guts periſht,
Then talke to me, before I ſcorne thy counſell,
Feele what I feele, and let my Lord repaire thee.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: And can the brave La-writ —

sp.speaker: 2 Cly.
sp.l: Tempt him no further,
Be warn'd and ſay no more.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: If thou doeſt, Sampſon,
Thou ſeeſt my Mirmidons, I'le let 'em looſe,
That in a moment—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: I ſay nothing, ſir, but I could wiſh—

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: They ſhall deſtroy thee wiſhing;
There's ne'r a man of theſe, but have loſt ten Cauſes,
Dearer then ten mens lives; tempt, and thou dieſt:
Goe home, and ſmile upon my Lord, mine Uncle,
Take Money of the men thou meaneſt to Cozen,
Drinke Wine, and eat good meat, and live diſcreetly,
Talke little, 'tis an Antidote againſt a beating;
Keep thy hand from thy ſword, and from thy Laundreſſe placket,
And thou wilt live long.

sp.speaker: 1 Cly.
sp.l: Give eare, and be inſtructed.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: I find I am wiſer then a Juſtice of Peace now,
Give me the wiſdome that's beaten into a man
That ſticks ſtill by him: art thou a new man?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Yes, yes,
Thy learned precepts have inchanted me,

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Goe my ſon Sampſon, I have now begot thee,
I'le ſend thee cauſes; ſpeake to thy Lord, and live.
And lay my ſhare by, goe and live in peace,
Put on new ſuites, and ſhew fit for thy place;
That man neglects his living, is an Aſſe: Exit. Samp.
Farewell; come chearly boyes, about our buſineſſe,
Now welcome tongue againe, hang Swords.

sp.speaker: 1 Cly.
sp.l: Sweet Advocate. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: I know not wench, they may call'em what they wil,
Outlawes, or theeves, but I am ſure, to me
One was an honeſt man, he us'd me well,
What I did, 'tis no matter, he complain'd not.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I muſt confeſſe, there was one bold with me too,
Some coy thing, would ſay rude, but 'tis no matter,
I was to pay a Waiting womans ranſome,
And I have don't, and I would pay't againe,
Were I taine to morrow

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Alas, there was no hurt,
If't be a ſin, for ſuch as live at hard meat,
And keepe a long Lent, in the woods as they doe,
To taſt a little fleſh,

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: God help the Courtiers,
That ly at racke and manger

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: I ſhall love
A theefe the better for this while I live,
They are men of a charitable vocation,
And give where there is need, and with diſcretion,
And put a good ſpeed penny in my purſe,
That has bin empty twenty yeares,

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Peace Nurſe,
Farewell, and cry not roſt meate, me thinkes Cleremont
And my Lady Anabell are in one night,
Familliarly acquainted.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: I obſerve it,
If ſhe have got a penny too.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: No more,
My Lord Mounſier Vertaigne the provoſt too,
Haſt and acquaint my Lady, Exit Nurſe and Charl.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Wonderous ſtrainge,

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: 'Tis true Sir, on my credit,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: On mine honour,

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I have bin provoſt-Marſhall twenty yeares,
And have truſſed up a thouſand of theſe raſcalls,
But ſo nere Paris yet, I never met with,
One of that Brotherhood.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: We to our coſt have,
But will you ſearch the wood

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: It is beſet,
They cannot ſcape us, Nothing makes me wonder,
So much as having you within their power
They let you goe; it was a Courteſy,
That French theeves uſe not often, I much pitty
The Gentle Ladyes, yet I know not how,
I rather hope then feare
sp.stage: Enter Dinant, Cleremont, Verdoone, Beaupre, Lamira, Anabell, Charlote, Nurſe.
sp.l: Are theſe the priſoners?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: We were ſuch

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Kill me not, exceſſe of joy,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: I ſee thou liveſt, but haſt thou had no fowle play

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: No on my ſoule, my uſage hath bin noble,
Far from all violence,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: How were you freed,
But kiſſe me firſt, wee'll talk of that at leaſure,
I am glad I have thee; Neice how you keepe off,
As you knew me not?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Sir, I am where
I owe moſt duty

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: 'Tis indeed moſt true Sir,
The man that ſhould have bin your bed fellow
Your Lordſhips Bedfellow, that could not ſmell out
A Virgin of ſixteene, that was your foole,
To make you merry, this poore ſimple fellow
Has met the maid agen, and now ſhe knowes,
He is a man,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: How! is ſhe diſhonoured?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Not unleſſe marriage be diſhonourable,
Heaven is a witneſſe of our happy contract
And the next Prieſt we meete ſhall warrant it
To all the world: I lay with her in jeaſt,
'Tis turn'd to earneſt now.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Is this true Neice

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Her bluſhing ſilence grants it; nay Sir ſtorme not
He is my friend, and I can make this good,
His birth and fortunes equall hers, your Lordſhip
Might have ſought out a worſe we are all friends too,
All differences end thus. Now Sir, unleſſe
You would raiſe new diſſentions make perfect
What is ſo well begun

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: That were not manly,

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Let me perſwade you,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Well God give you joy,
She ſhall not come a Begger to you Sir,
For you Monſieur Dinant 'ere long i'll ſhew you,
Another Neico, to this not much inferiour,
As you ſhall like proceed

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I thanke you Sir,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Backe then to Paris, well that travell ends
That makes of deadly enemies perfect friends.

div.head: Prologue.
div.l: TO promiſe much, before a play begin,
And when 'tis done, aske pardon, were a ſinne
Wee'll not be guilty of: and to excuſe
Before we know a fault were to abuſe
The writers and our ſelves, for I dare ſay
We all are foold if this be not a Playe
And ſuch a play as ſhall, (ſo ſhould playes doe)
Impe times dull wings, and make you merry too
'Twas to that purpoſe writ, ſo we intend it
And we have our wiſht ends, if you commend it.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: I Am ſent forth to enquire what you decree
Of us and our Poets, they will be
This night exceeding merry, ſo will we
If you approve their labours. They profeſſe
You are their patrons, and we ſay no leſſe,
Reſolve us then, for you can onely tell
Whither we have done id'ly or done well.
